text: In the thirtieth year, in the fourth month, on the fifth day of the month, when I was among the exiles by the Kebar Canal, the heavens were opened, and I saw visions of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the fifth of that month, in the fifth year of the exile of King Jehoiachin,
speaker: Narrator

text: the word of the Lord came in a dramatic way upon Ezekiel, the son of Buzi, the priest, in the land of the Chaldeans, by the Kebar Canal, and the hand of the Lord was upon him there.
speaker: Narrator

text: As I watched, I noticed a windstorm coming from the north. There was a large cloud, with fire flashing through it, and there was a bright light all around it. In the middle of it, there was something that looked like glowing metal in the middle of the fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the middle of it I saw what looked like four living creatures. This was what they looked like. Each of them had a human appearance,
speaker: Narrator

text: but each one had four faces, and each of them had four wings.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each of their legs was straight, and their feet were like a calf’s hoof, and they gleamed like polished bronze.
speaker: Narrator

text: They had human hands under their wings on all four of their sides. All four of them had faces and wings.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their wings were touching one another. The creatures did not turn from side to side as they moved, but each one faced straight ahead.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what their faces looked like. Each one had a face like a man’s face. On the right side of their heads, all four of them had a face like a lion. On the left side, all four of them had a face like an ox. All four of them also had a face like an eagle.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those were their faces.
Their wings were stretched upward. Each of them had one pair of wings which touched the wings of each of the cherubs next to it and another pair of wings which covered their bodies.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each one faced straight ahead as it moved. They went in whatever direction the spirit wanted to go. They did not turn as they moved ahead.
speaker: Narrator

text: The appearance of the living creatures was like red-hot coals, like the appearance of blazing torches. Fire was moving back and forth among the living creatures. The fire was bright, and lightning was coming out of the fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: The creatures darted back and forth. They looked like jagged bolts of lightning.
speaker: Narrator

text: As I looked at the living creatures, I noticed one wheel on the ground beside each one of the living creatures that had four faces.
speaker: Narrator

text: The appearance of the wheels and their design were like the sparkle of topaz, and the four of them looked alike. Their appearance and their design were like a wheel within a wheel.
speaker: Narrator

text: They could go in any of the four directions when they moved, but the wheels did not turn from side to side when they moved.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for their rims, they were high and intimidating, and their rims were full of eyes all the way around—all four of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whenever the living creatures moved, the wheels moved beside them, and whenever the living creatures would rise from the ground, the wheels rose too.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wherever the spirit wanted to go, they would go. Wherever the spirit wanted to go, the wheels would rise together with them, because the spirit of the living creature was in the wheels.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whenever the living creatures moved, the wheels would move. Whenever the living creatures stood still, the wheels would stand still. Whenever the living creatures rose from the ground, the wheels would rise together with them, because the spirit of the living creature was in the wheels.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was something above the heads of the living creatures like the dome of a vaulted ceiling. It looked like ice. It was spectacular. It stretched out above their heads.
speaker: Narrator

text: Under the dome, two of their wings were stretched out to touch the wing of another one of the creatures. Each of the creatures also had two wings covering themselves, each had two wings covering themselves—covering their bodies.
speaker: Narrator

text: I heard the sound of their wings, like the sound of rushing water. It was like the voice of the Almighty when they moved—a sound of commotion, like the noise in an army camp. When they stood still, they lowered their wings.
speaker: Narrator

text: A voice came from above the dome that was over their heads. When they stood still, they lowered their wings.
speaker: Narrator

text: Above the dome that was over their heads, there was something that appeared to be a sapphire that was shaped like a throne. Seated on that throne-like form there was a figure that looked like a man.
speaker: Narrator

text: I saw something like the gleam of glowing metal with fire in it and all around it. It extended upward from what appeared to be the man’s waist. Below what appeared to be his waist, I saw what appeared to be fire, and a bright light surrounded him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The bright light that surrounded him looked like the rainbow that is in the clouds on a rainy day.
This was the appearance of the likeness of the Glory of the Lord. When I saw this, I fell on my face, and I heard a voice speaking.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to me, “Son of man, stand up on your feet, and I will speak with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Spirit entered into me as he spoke to me and brought me up to my feet. Then I heard him speaking to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to me, “Son of man, I am sending you to the people of Israel, to disloyal nations, who have been disloyal to me. They and their fathers have rebelled against me to this very day.
speaker: Narrator

text: These children of mine are brazen-faced and hard-hearted. I am sending you to them, and you are to tell them that this is what the Lord God says.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then, whether they listen or do not listen—for they are a rebellious house—then they will know that a prophet has been among them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you, son of man, do not be afraid of them, and do not be afraid of their words. Even though briers and thorns surround you and you are living with scorpions, do not be afraid of their words, and do not be intimidated by the look on their faces, for they are a rebellious house.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to speak my words to them whether they listen or they do not, for they are rebellious.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you, son of man, listen to what I am telling you. Do not be rebellious like that rebellious house. Open your mouth and eat what I am giving you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I looked, and I saw a hand stretched out toward me, and in it there was a rolled-up scroll.
speaker: Narrator

text: He unrolled it in front of me, and there was writing on both sides. Written on it was: Laments, Groaning, and Woe.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said to me, “Son of man, eat what you have received. Eat this scroll, and then go, speak to the house of Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: I opened my mouth, and he fed me the scroll.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said to me, “Son of man, feed your stomach and fill your belly with this scroll that I am giving you.” I ate, and in my mouth it was sweet like honey.
speaker: Narrator

text: He then said to me, “Son of man, go now to the house of Israel and speak my words to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: For you are not being sent to a people who have incomprehensible speech or a difficult language, but you are being sent to the house of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nor are you being sent to many peoples who have incomprehensible speech and difficult languages, whose words you cannot understand. Certainly, if I were to send you to such people, they would listen to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the house of Israel will not be willing to listen to you because they are not willing to listen to me, because the whole house of Israel is hard-headed and hard-hearted.
speaker: Narrator

text: Look, I have made your face just as hard as their faces and your forehead just as hard as their foreheads.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have made your forehead like the hardest stone, harder than flint. Do not fear them, and do not be intimidated by their looks, for they are a rebellious house.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said to me, “Son of man, receive into your heart all my words that I will speak to you, and hear them with your ears.
speaker: Narrator

text: Go now to the exiles, to your own people. You shall speak to them and say to them, ‘This is what the Lord God says,’ whether they listen or they do not.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Spirit lifted me up, and I heard a loud rushing sound behind me—Blessed be the Glory of the Lord in its dwelling place!—
speaker: Narrator

text: It was the sound of the wings of the living creatures beating against each other and the sound of the wheels beside them, a loud rumbling sound.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Spirit lifted me up and took me away, and so I went, bitter and heated in my spirit, and the hand of the Lord was upon me with power.
speaker: Narrator

text: I came to the exiles at Tel Aviv, who were living by the Kebar Canal—there where they were living. I sat among them for seven days—stunned.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the end of seven days the word of the Lord came to me and said:
speaker: Narrator

text: Son of man, I have appointed you as a watchman for the house of Israel. When you hear a word from my mouth, you must give them a warning from me.
speaker: Narrator

text: When I announce to a wicked man, “You shall surely die,” if you do not warn him, and you do not speak up to warn the wicked man against his wicked way so that he can live, then that wicked man will die because of his guilt, and I will hold you responsible for his blood.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you, if you warn the wicked man, and he does not turn from his wickedness or from his wicked way, he shall die because of his guilt, but you will have saved your own life.
speaker: Narrator

text: Or when a righteous man turns away from his righteousness and becomes unrighteous, and I place a stumbling block in front of him, he shall die. If you have not warned him, he shall die in his sin, and his righteous deeds which he had done will not be remembered, and I will hold you responsible for his blood.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you, if you do warn that righteous man not to sin, and he does not sin, he shall certainly live because he heeded the warning, and you will have saved your own life.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the hand of the Lord was upon me there, and he said to me, “Get up, go out to the center of the river valley, and there I will speak with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So I got up and went out to the center of the valley, and suddenly there it was! The Glory of the Lord was standing there, just like the Glory that I had seen by the Kebar Canal, and I fell on my face.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But the Spirit entered into me and brought me to my feet.
Then he spoke to me and said to me, “Go, shut yourself up inside your house.
speaker: Narrator

text: And this is what will happen to you, son of man. They will certainly place ropes upon you and tie you up with them, so that you will not be able to go out among them.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will make your tongue stick to the roof of your mouth, so that you will be speechless, and you will not be able to rebuke them, for they are a rebellious house.
speaker: Narrator

text: But whenever I speak to you, I will open your mouth, and you shall say to them, ‘This is what the Lord God says.’ Whoever listens, let him listen. Whoever refuses to listen, let him refuse, for they are a rebellious house.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now you, son of man, take a brick for yourself, place it in front of you, and sketch on it a city, which is Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lay siege against it, build a siege wall against it, heap up a ramp against it, set up camps against it, and station battering rams against it, all the way around it.
speaker: Narrator

text: And you, take an iron griddle and set it up as an iron wall between you and the city. Direct your face toward it, so that it will be under siege as you besiege it. This will be a sign for the house of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: And you, lie down on your left side, and place the guilt of the house of Israel on it. For as many days as you lie on your side, you shall bear their guilt.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will assign to you the number of days you are to lie on your side on the basis of the number of years of their guilt: three hundred ninety days. So you shall bear the guilt of the house of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you have finished these days, you shall lie down a second time on your right side, and you shall bear the guilt of the house of Judah for forty days. I have assigned to you one day for each year.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall direct your face toward the siege of Jerusalem, with your arm bared, and you shall prophesy against it.
speaker: Narrator

text: See, I have placed ropes upon you, so that you will not turn from your one side to your other side until you finish the days of your siege.
speaker: Narrator

text: And you, take some wheat, barley, beans, lentils, millet, and emmer wheat for yourself. You shall put them in a single dish and make bread for yourself with them. During the whole number of days that you are lying on your side—three hundred ninety days—you shall eat it.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall weigh out the food you eat—half a pound a day. You are to eat it at set times each day.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall measure the water you drink—a pint and a half a day. You are to drink it at set times each day.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to eat it as you would eat flat bread made of barley, and you are to bake it over balls of human excrement in their sight.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said, “This is how the people of Israel will eat their food: They will be ceremonially unclean among the nations where I will banish them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I said, “Oh no, Lord God, I have never made myself unclean. I have never eaten a carcass or something torn by wild animals, from my youth until now. Neither has any meat which is ceremonially unclean ever entered my mouth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he answered me, “Very well, I will let you use droppings of cattle instead of balls of human excrement, and you shall bake your bread over them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He also said this to me: “Son of man, watch for this! I am about to take away the bread supply from Jerusalem, and they will measure out their bread by weight and eat it with anxiety, and they will measure out their water and drink it with horror.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they will lack food and water, and they will be horrified, each man and his brother, and they will waste away because of their guilt.”
speaker: Narrator

text: You, son of man, get a sharp sword for yourself. You shall use it on yourself like a barber’s razor. Use it on your head and on your beard. Then get scales for yourself so that you can weigh and divide the hair.
speaker: Narrator

text: One third of it you shall burn with fire inside the city when the days of siege are completed. Then you shall take another third and strike it with the sword all around the city. Another third you shall scatter to the wind, but I will unsheathe the sword to pursue them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But take a few hairs and wrap them in the folds of your robe.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then take some of those and throw them into the middle of the fire and burn them up in the fire. From there a fire will spread to the whole house of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Lord God says. This is Jerusalem. I have set her in the midst of the nations, and all around her there are other countries.
speaker: Narrator

text: But she rebelled against my ordinances, becoming more wicked than the nations, and she rebelled against my statutes more than the countries around her did, because the Israelites rejected my ordinances, and they did not walk in my statutes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, this is what the Lord God says. Because you have outdone the nations around you, and you have not walked in my statutes, and you have not performed what I judged to be right, and you have not even acted according to the standards of justice followed by the nations around you,
speaker: Narrator

text: therefore, this is what the Lord God says. Watch out! I am against you. I myself will perform judgments among you in the sight of the nations.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will do among you something that I have never done before and the likes of which I shall never do again, because of all your abominations.
speaker: Narrator

text: That is why fathers among you will eat their sons, and sons will eat their fathers. I will execute judgments against you, and I will scatter any of you who are left to every wind.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, as surely as I live, declares the Lord God, because you have defiled my sanctuary by all your detestable practices and all your abominations, I, yes I myself, will withdraw. My eye will not show pity, and I myself will have no compassion.
speaker: Narrator

text: A third of you will die in the plague or perish during the famine in your midst. All around you, a third will fall by the sword, and a third I will scatter to every wind. Then I will unsheathe the sword in pursuit of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Finally, my anger will be finished. I will let my wrath against them rest, and I will be satisfied. Then they will know that I, the Lord, have spoken in my jealousy—when I exhaust my wrath against them.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will make you into a ruin and a reproach among the nations around you, in the sight of everyone who passes by.
speaker: Narrator

text: You, Jerusalem, will be a reproach and a taunt, a warning and something horrifying to the nations around you, when I execute judgments upon you in anger, in wrath, and in furious punishments. I, the Lord, have spoken.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will also send deadly arrows of famine against them, arrows that shall become a destroyer, arrows that I will send to destroy you. I will also increase the famine upon you and cut off your supply of bread.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will send famine and dangerous wild animals against you, and they will take away your children from you. Plague and bloodshed will pass through you, and I will bring the sword against you. I, the Lord, have spoken.
speaker: Narrator

text: The word of the Lord came to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Son of man, set your face toward the mountains of Israel and prophesy against them.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall say, “Mountains of Israel, hear the word of the Lord God.” This is what the Lord God says to the mountains and to the hills, to the streambeds and to the valleys. Without fail, I am about to bring a sword against you, and I will destroy your high places.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your altars will be demolished, and your incense altars will be smashed, and I will throw down your fallen bodies in front of your filthy idols.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will lay out the corpses of the people of Israel in front of their filthy idols, and I will scatter your bones around your altars.
speaker: Narrator

text: In all the places where you live, the towns will be laid waste, and the high places will be demolished, so that your altars will be laid waste and demolished, your filthy idols will be crushed and cease to exist, your incense altars will be broken in pieces, and the things you have made will be wiped out.
speaker: Narrator

text: The slain will fall in your midst, and then you will know that I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nevertheless, when you are scattered in various countries, I will preserve for you some survivors who escape the sword among the nations.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then, those of you who escape will remember me in the nations where they have been carried as captives. They will remember how I was heartbroken by their lustful hearts, which turned away from me, and by their eyes, which lusted for their filthy idols. They will loathe themselves because of all the evils they have done, for all their abominations.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they will know that I, the Lord, did not speak about bringing this disaster on them without it having a result.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Lord God says. Clap your hands, stomp your feet, and say, “We are doomed,” on account of all the vile abominations of the house of Israel, for by the sword, famine, and plague they will fall.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone who is far away will die of the plague, and anyone who is near will fall by the sword, and anyone who remains under siege will die of famine. In this way I will exhaust my wrath upon them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you will know that I am the Lord, when their fallen bodies lie among their filthy idols around their altars, on every high hill and on all the mountaintops, under every green tree and under every leafy oak, in every place where they offered fragrant sacrifice to appease all their filthy idols.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will stretch out my hand against them, and I will make the land a desolate waste from the desert to Riblah, in all the places they live. Then they will know that I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The word of the Lord came to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: And to you, son of man, this is what the Lord God says about the soil of Israel. An end! The end has come upon the four corners of the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now that the end is upon you, I will unleash my anger against you. I will judge you according to your ways, and I will place on you the penalty for all your abominations.
speaker: Narrator

text: My eye will not have pity on you, and I will have no compassion, for I will place on you the penalty for your ways, and the punishment for your abominations will be in your midst. Then you will know that I am the Lord!
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Lord God says. Disaster! An unparalleled disaster! Watch, it is coming!
speaker: Narrator

text: An end has come! The end has come! It has begun against you. Look, it is coming!
speaker: Narrator

text: Doom has come upon you, you inhabitants of the land. The time has come, the day is near. A day of panic, not joy, is on the mountains.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now very soon I will pour out my wrath upon you, and I will exhaust my anger against you. I will judge you according to your ways, and I will place on you the penalty for all your abominations.
speaker: Narrator

text: My eye will not show pity, and I will have no compassion. According to your ways I will place the penalty on you, and the punishment for your abominations will be in your midst. Then you will know that I, the Lord, am the one who strikes you!
speaker: Narrator

text: Look, the day is coming. It is here. Doom has broken out. The rod has budded. Insolence has blossomed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Violence has grown into a rod against wickedness. None of them will remain—none of their noisy crowd, none of their wealth, not a thing of value among them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The time has come; the day has arrived.
The buyer should not rejoice. The seller should not grieve, because wrath is coming upon the whole noisy crowd.
speaker: Narrator

text: So sellers will not return to what they have sold, even if they survive. Yes, the vision concerning the whole noisy crowd will not be reversed, and each man, because of the guilt in his life, will have no strength.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will blow a blast on the ram’s horn and make everything ready, but no one will go to battle, because my wrath is upon the whole noisy crowd.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sword is outside, and plague and famine are inside. Anyone in the countryside will die by the sword, and anyone in the city—plague and famine will devour him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Any who escape will flee to the mountains, mourning like doves from the valley, each of them in his guilt.
speaker: Narrator

text: All hands will hang limp, and water will run down every knee.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will put on sackcloth, and horror will cover them. Every face will be ashamed, and all their heads will be shaved bald.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will throw their silver into the streets, and their gold will be polluted by blood. Their silver and their gold will not be able to rescue them on the day of the Lord’s fury. The silver and gold will not satisfy their appetites or fill their stomachs, because it was the cause of their guilt and their downfall.
speaker: Narrator

text:
From the silver and gold of the Lord’s beautiful ornaments, which were their pride, they made their abominations and their disgusting images.
Therefore, for them I will make it a place polluted by blood.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will hand it over to foreigners as loot. I will give it to the most wicked people on earth as plunder, and they will desecrate it.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will turn my face away from my people so that the enemy may desecrate my treasured place, and so that robbers may enter it and desecrate it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Prepare the chain, because the earth is full of judicial murder, and the city is full of violence.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will bring the most wicked of the nations, and they will take possession of their houses. I will put an end to the pride of the mighty, and their so-called sanctuaries will be desecrated.
speaker: Narrator

text: Terror is coming. They will seek peace, but there will be none.
speaker: Narrator

text: Disaster after disaster will come, and one report will follow another. They will seek a vision from the prophet, but sound instruction will vanish from the priest and the ability to give advice from the elders.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king will mourn, the prince will be clothed with horror, and the hands of the people of the land will tremble. On the basis of their own conduct I will deal with them, and by the standard they used to judge others I will judge them. Then they will know that I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the sixth year, in the sixth month, on the fifth day of the month, I was sitting in my house, and the elders of Judah were sitting in front of me. The hand of the Lord God fell upon me there.
speaker: Narrator

text: I looked, and there I saw a figure that looked like a man. From what appeared to be his waist down, he looked like fire, and from his waist up, he had the appearance of a dazzling light, something like glowing metal.
speaker: Narrator

text: He reached out with what looked like a hand and seized me by a lock of hair. Then the Spirit lifted me up between earth and heaven and brought me to Jerusalem, while I was experiencing visions from God. He brought me to the entrance of the north gate into the inner courtyard of the Temple, where the idolatrous image of jealousy, which provokes jealousy, was located.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I looked, and there was the Glory of the God of Israel, as it was in the vision that I had seen in the middle of the river valley.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to me, “Son of man, look toward the north.” So I looked toward the north, and what did I see! There, north of the altar gate, was this idolatrous image of jealousy beside the entrance.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to me, “Son of man, do you see what they are doing—what great abominations the house of Israel is practicing here, to distance themselves from my sanctuary! But you will see even greater abominations.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Next, he brought me to the entrance to the courtyard, and I looked and saw that there was a hole in the wall.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to me, “Son of man, dig through the wall.” So I dug through the wall, and there I saw a doorway.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to me, “Go in and observe the vile abominations that they are committing here.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When I entered, I looked around, and what did I see! Every form of creeping creature and every kind of detestable animal and all the filthy idols of the house of Israel were engraved on the wall, all around.
speaker: Narrator

text: Seventy men of the elders of the house of Israel—with Ja’azaniah son of Shaphan standing in the middle—were standing in front of the images, each with his censer in his hand, and the fragrance of the cloud of incense was ascending.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to me, “Do you see, son of man, what the elders of the house of Israel are doing in the darkness, each in his chamber for carved images? Listen! They are saying, ‘The Lord does not see us. The Lord has forsaken the land.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said to me, “You will see even greater abominations which they are practicing.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Next, he brought me to the entrance of the gateway of the House of the Lord that is on the north side, and right there I saw women sitting and wailing for Tammuz.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to me, “Do you see, son of man? You will see even greater abominations than these.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Finally, he brought me to the inner courtyard of the House of the Lord, and there at the entrance to the temple of the Lord, between the vestibule and the altar, were twenty-five men, showing their backsides to the temple of the Lord with their faces toward the east, and they were bowing down to the sun in the east.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said to me, “Have you seen this, son of man? Is it too trivial for the house of Judah to commit the abominations they are committing here? Do they also have to fill the land with violence, so that they provoke me more and more? They are even sticking the branch up my nose!
speaker: Narrator

text: But I also will act in wrath. My eye will not show pity, and I will have no compassion. They will call out to my ears with a loud cry, but I will not hear them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he called out with a loud voice in my hearing, “Bring the supervisors of the city here, each one of them with his weapon of destruction in his hand.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I noticed six men coming from the direction of the upper gate that faces north, each with his weapon, a war club, in his hand. There was also one man in the middle, dressed in linen, with a scribe’s kit at his waist. They entered and stood beside the bronze altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the Glory of the God of Israel ascended from above the cherub, over whom it had been standing, and moved to the threshold of the temple building. He called out to the man who was dressed in linen, who had the scribe’s kit at his waist.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to him, “Go through the city, through Jerusalem, and put a cross mark on the foreheads of those who moan and lament over the abominations being committed in her.”
speaker: Narrator

text: To the others he said in my hearing, “Follow him through the city and strike the people down. Do not let your eye show pity, and do not have compassion.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Old men and young men, virgins, little children, and women—you are to keep killing until you wipe them out completely. But do not go near anyone who has been marked with the cross. You are to begin at my sanctuary.”
So they began with the old men who were in front of the temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said to them, “Defile the temple and fill the courts with the slain. Go!” So they went and struck them down throughout the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: While they were striking them down, I was left alone and I fell facedown and cried out, “Oh, Lord God! Are you going to destroy everyone who is left in Israel, as you pour out your wrath upon Jerusalem?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to me, “The guilt of the house of Israel and Judah is very, very great. The land is filled with bloodshed, and the city is full of injustice, because they say, ‘The Lord has forsaken the land’ and ‘The Lord does not see.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But I am determined that my eye will show no pity, and I will have no compassion. I will bring down their conduct on their own heads.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Just then, I saw the man dressed in linen, who had the scribe’s kit at his waist. He was reporting, “I have done just as you commanded me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I looked, and there, above the vaulted ceiling that was over the heads of the cherubim, there was something that looked like a sapphire, shaped like a throne. It could be seen above the cherubim.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to the man dressed in linen, “Reach into the structure for the wheels that is beneath the cherubim, fill your cupped hands with fiery coals from among the cherubim, and scatter them over the city.” So he went in while I watched.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the cherubim were standing on the south side of the temple while he, the man, approached, and the cloud filled the inner courtyard.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Glory of the Lord rose from above the cherubim and moved to the threshold of the temple. The temple was filled with the cloud, and the courtyard was full of the radiance of the Glory of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sound of the wings of the cherubim was heard as far away as the outer courtyard, like the voice of God Almighty when he speaks.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he commanded the man dressed in linen, “Take fire from between the wheels, from between the cherubim,” the man went and stood beside the wheel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then a cherub stretched out his hand from among the cherubim and reached into the fire that was between the cherubim. He lifted up some coals, and he put them into the cupped hands of the man dressed in linen, and the man took them and went out.
speaker: Narrator

text: The cherubim had something that seemed like the form of a human hand under their wings.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I looked, and right there beside the cherubim were four wheels, one wheel beside each cherub, and the wheels looked like topaz.
speaker: Narrator

text: The four of them all looked alike—there was a wheel inside each wheel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The cherubim could move in any of the four directions toward which one of them faced, without turning as they moved. They went straight ahead in the direction they faced, never turning from side to side.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their entire body, their back, their hands, their wings, and the wheels were full of eyes all around. (I mean the wheels that belonged to the four of them.)
speaker: Narrator

text: As for the wheels, they were called “wheelwork” in my hearing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each one of the cherubim had four faces. One face was the face of a cherub. The second face was the face of a man. The third was the face of a lion, and the fourth was the face of an eagle.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the cherubim rose. These were the living creatures that I had seen by the Kebar Canal.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whenever the cherubim moved, the wheels moved alongside them, and whenever the cherubim lifted up their wings to rise from the ground, the wheels did not turn away from their side.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the cherubim stood still, the wheels would stand still, and when the cherubim rose, the wheels would rise with them, because the spirit of the living creatures was in the wheels.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Glory of the Lord moved out from the threshold of the temple and took a position above the cherubim.
speaker: Narrator

text: As I watched, the cherubim lifted up their wings and rose from the ground. As they went out, the wheels remained beside them. They stopped at the entrance of the east gate of the House of the Lord, and the Glory of the God of Israel was above the cherubim.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the living creatures that I had seen beneath the God of Israel at the Kebar Canal, and I now knew that they were cherubim.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each one had four faces, and each had four wings, with something like the hands of a man underneath their wings.
speaker: Narrator

text: The faces looked like the faces that I had seen by the Kebar Canal—exactly the same. Each one went straight ahead.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Spirit lifted me up and brought me to the east gate of the temple of the Lord, which faces east. There, at the entrance to the gateway, were twenty-five men, and among them I saw Ja’azaniah son of Azzur and Pelatiah son of Benaiah, leaders of the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to me, “Son of man, these are the men who are plotting evil and giving wicked advice in this city,
speaker: Narrator

text: who are saying, ‘We will not have to build houses anytime soon. The city is the pot, and we are the meat.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, prophesy against them. Prophesy, son of man.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the Spirit of the Lord fell upon me, and he told me to say this.
This is what the Lord says. This is what you are saying, house of Israel. I know what you have in mind.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have killed many people in this city and filled its streets with the slain.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, this is what the Lord God says. Your slain, which you have placed within the city, are the meat, and the city is the pot. But I will drive you out of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sword is what you have feared, and I will bring the sword upon you, declares the Lord God.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will drive you out from it, hand you over to foreigners, and execute judgments on you.
speaker: Narrator

text: By the sword you will fall, and at the border of Israel I will judge you. Then you will know that I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: This city will not be a pot for you, and you will not be the meat inside it. At the border of Israel I will judge you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you will know that I am the Lord, in whose statutes you have not walked and whose ordinances you have not obeyed, but instead you have acted according to the ordinances of the nations around you.
speaker: Narrator

text: While I was prophesying, Pelatiah son of Benaiah died. Then I fell facedown and cried out in a loud voice. I said, “Oh no, Lord God, you are making a complete destruction of the remaining survivors of Israel!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the word of the Lord came to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Son of man, your brothers, your brothers who have the right to redeem your property, and the whole house of Israel—all of it—to whom the inhabitants of Jerusalem are saying, “Stay far away from the Lord! This land has been given to us as a possession.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Tell them that this is what the Lord God says.
Although I have removed them far away among the nations, and I have indeed scattered them among the lands, I will be a sanctuary for them for a little while in the lands to which they have gone.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore say, “This is what the Lord God says.” I will gather you from the peoples and assemble you from the lands where you have been scattered, and I will give you the land of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they arrive back there, they will remove from it all its loathsome things and all its abominations.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will give them one heart, and I will put a new spirit within you. I will remove the heart of stone from their body and give them a heart of flesh,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that they will walk in my statutes and keep my ordinances and carry them out. They will be my people, and I will be their God.
speaker: Narrator

text: But as for those whose heart goes after their disgusting things and their abominations, I will bring down their conduct on their own heads, declares the Lord God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the cherubim lifted up their wings. The wheels were beside them, and the Glory of the God of Israel was positioned above them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Glory of the Lord went up from the middle of the city and stood on the mountain east of the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Spirit lifted me up and brought me to the exiles in Chaldea, in the vision from the Spirit of God. Then the vision I had seen departed from me, and I told the exiles all the things from the Lord that he had shown to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: The word of the Lord came to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Son of man, you are living in the middle of a rebellious house. They have eyes to see, but they do not see, and they have ears to hear, but they do not hear, because they are a rebellious house.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, you, son of man, pack your baggage for exile, and depart into exile during the daytime, while they are watching. You are to depart into exile from your place to another place, while they are watching. Perhaps they will see that they are a rebellious house.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to bring out your baggage, packed for exile, during the daytime, while they are watching. Then in the evening, while they are watching, you are to go out like someone going into exile.
speaker: Narrator

text: While they are watching, dig through the wall, and bring out your baggage through it.
speaker: Narrator

text: While they are watching, lift it up on your shoulder, and carry it out at dusk. Cover your face so that you cannot see the ground, for I have made you a warning sign to the house of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: I did that, exactly as I was commanded. I brought out my baggage, packed for exile, during the daytime, and then in the evening I dug through the wall by hand. When it was getting dark, I brought my baggage out. I carried it on my shoulder while they were watching.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the morning the word of the Lord came to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Son of man, hasn’t the house of Israel, that rebellious house, asked you, ‘What are you doing?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
You are to tell them that this is what the Lord God says.”
This burdensome prophecy is about the burdensome prince in Jerusalem, together with the whole house of Israel who are in its midst.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Say to them, “I am a warning sign for you.”
Exactly what I have done will be done to them. Into exile, into captivity, they will go.
speaker: Narrator

text: The prince who is in their midst will carry his baggage on his shoulder at dusk and go out. They will dig through the wall to bring him out through it. He will cover his face, so he will not see the ground with his own eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will spread out my net for him, and he will be caught in my trap. I will bring him to Babylon, to the land of the Chaldeans, but he will not see it, and there he will die.
speaker: Narrator

text: All those who are around him, his aides and all his troops, I will scatter to every wind, and I will unsheathe my sword against them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they will know that I am the Lord, when I scatter them among the nations and disperse them across many countries.
speaker: Narrator

text: But from among them I will let a small number survive the sword, famine, and plague, in order that they may tell about all their abominations among the nations where they go. Then they will know that I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The word of the Lord came to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Son of man, you are to eat your food with trembling, and you are to drink your water with shuddering and anxiety.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to say to the people of the land: This is what the Lord God says about the inhabitants of Jerusalem on the soil of Israel. They will eat their food with anxiety and drink their water with horror, because everything that filled the land will be devastated because of the violence of all its inhabitants.
speaker: Narrator

text: The inhabited cities will be laid waste, and the land will be devastated. Then you will know that I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The word of the Lord came to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Son of man, what is this saying that you have about the homeland of Israel: “The days keep going by, and every vision fails”?
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore say this to them. This is what the Lord God says. I will put an end to this saying, and they will no longer use it as a saying in Israel. On the contrary, say to them, “The days are near when every vision will be fulfilled.”
speaker: Narrator

text: For no longer will there be any empty, unreliable visions or slippery, misleading omens within the house of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I am the Lord. Whatever word I speak will be fulfilled. It will be delayed no longer. For in your own days, you rebellious house, I will speak a word and fulfill it, declares the Lord God.
speaker: Narrator

text: The word of the Lord came to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Son of man, listen to what the house of Israel is saying: “The vision that he is seeing is for many days in the future, and he is prophesying for distant times.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, tell the Israelites this is what the Lord God says. None of my words will be delayed any longer, because I will speak a word and it will be fulfilled, declares the Lord God.
speaker: Narrator

text: The word of the Lord came to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Son of man, prophesy against the prophets of Israel who are prophesying. You are to say to the prophets who prophesy from their own heart: Hear the word of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Lord God says. Woe to the foolish prophets who follow their own spirit and prophesy things which they have not seen.
speaker: Narrator

text: Israel, your prophets are like jackals among the ruins.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have not stepped up into the breaks in the wall, nor have you repaired the wall for the house of Israel, so that it could stand up in battle on the Day of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: They see empty visions and their omens predict lies—those who say, “The declaration of the Lord,” when the Lord has not sent them, and yet they expect him to fulfill their word.
speaker: Narrator

text: Have you not, in fact, seen an empty vision and predicted lies when you say, “The declaration of the Lord,” when, in fact, I have not spoken?
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, this is what the Lord God says. Because you have spoken empty words and have seen a lying vision, therefore, I am surely against you, declares the Lord God.
speaker: Narrator

text: My hand will come upon the prophets who see empty visions and predict a lie. They will not remain in the council of my people. They will not be recorded in the register of the house of Israel, and they will not enter the land of Israel. Then you will know that I am the Lord God.
speaker: Narrator

text: This will happen precisely because they have misled my people by saying, “Peace,” when there is no peace. When someone builds a flimsy wall, look how the false prophets daub it with a coat of mud plaster.
speaker: Narrator

text: Tell those who are daubing with plaster that the wall will fall. There will be driving rain, large hailstones will fall, and a violent wind will break out,
speaker: Narrator

text: and suddenly the wall will fall. Won’t they say to you, “Where is the mud plaster you daubed on now?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, this is what the Lord God says. In my wrath I will make a violent wind break out, and there will be driving rain because of my anger. In my wrath I will send large hailstones that bring destruction.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will demolish the wall that you have daubed with mud plaster. I will level it to the ground, so that its foundation will be exposed. It will fall, and you will perish within the city. Then you will know that I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: In this way I will exhaust my wrath against the wall and against those who daubed it with mud plaster, and I will say to you, “Gone is the wall, and gone are those who daubed on it—
speaker: Narrator

text: those prophets of Israel who are prophesying about Jerusalem and who proclaim a vision of peace about her when there is no peace, declares the Lord God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: You, son of man, are to set your face against the daughters of your people, who are prophesying ecstatically from their own hearts. You are to prophesy against them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You are to say that this is what the Lord God says.
Woe to those women who sew magic bands for all their wrists and who make veils of every size for people’s heads in order to trap souls. Will you women trap the souls of my people, but preserve your own souls?
speaker: Narrator

text: You women profane me among my people for handfuls of barley and scraps of bread, killing people who should not die and keeping people alive who should not live. You do this by your lying to my people—those who listen to lies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore, this is what the Lord God says.
Listen. I am against your magic bands, with which you women trap souls like birds. I will tear them from your arms, and I will set free the souls that you trap like birds.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will tear off your veils and rescue my people from your hand. They will no longer be in your hand like prey. Then you will know that I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because you have disheartened the righteous man with delusions, even though I have not intended to grieve him, and you have strengthened the hands of the wicked man, so that he does not repent of his evil way, and so he does not save his life,
speaker: Narrator

text: therefore, you women will no longer proclaim empty words, and you will no longer deceive with false omens. I will rescue my people from your hand. Then you will know that I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some men from the elders of Israel came to me and sat down in front of me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the word of the Lord came to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Son of man, these men have set up their filthy idols in their hearts, and they have placed a stumbling block that makes them guilty in front of their faces. So should I really let them consult me?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore, speak with them and tell them this is what the Lord God says.
Whenever anyone from the house of Israel sets up his filthy idols in his heart or sets the stumbling block that makes him guilty in front of his face and he then comes to a prophet, I, the Lord, will give him an answer appropriate to the multitude of his filthy idols,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that I may capture the hearts of the house of Israel, for all of them have alienated themselves from me with their filthy idols.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, tell the house of Israel that this is what the Lord God says. Repent and turn away from your filthy idols, and turn your faces away from all your abominations.
speaker: Narrator

text: Certainly, anyone from the house of Israel or an alien who is residing in Israel, if he alienates himself from me and sets up his filthy idols in his heart and puts the stumbling block that makes him guilty in front of his face, and he then comes to a prophet to seek my guidance for himself, I myself, the Lord, will give him an answer.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will set my face against that man, and I will make him into a sign and a notorious example, and I will cut him off from among my people. Then you will know that I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a prophet acts like a fool and speaks a message, I, the Lord, have made a fool of that prophet. I will stretch out my hand against him, and I will destroy him from among my people Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will bear their guilt. The guilt of the one who seeks guidance will be the same as the guilt of the prophet,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that the house of Israel will no longer stray from following me, and they will never again defile themselves by all their rebellious acts. They will be my people, and I will be their God, declares the Lord God.
speaker: Narrator

text: The word of the Lord came to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Son of man, when a land sins against me by adding one act of infidelity to another, so that I stretch out my hand against it to cut off its bread supply, to send famine against it, and to cut off man and beast from it,
speaker: Narrator

text: even if these three men were in its midst—Noah, Daniel, and Job—by their righteousness they would save only their own lives, declares the Lord God.
speaker: Narrator

text: If I cause wild animals to pass through the land and they rob it of its children, so that it becomes desolate, and no one can pass through because of the wild animals,
speaker: Narrator

text: and if these three men were in its midst, as I live, says the Lord God, they would not save either their sons or their daughters. They alone would be saved, but the land would be devastated.
speaker: Narrator

text: Or if I bring a sword upon that land and say, “A sword shall pass through the land,” and I cut off from it man and beast,
speaker: Narrator

text: and these three men were in its midst, as I live, says the Lord God, they would not be able to save either their sons or their daughters, but they alone would be saved.
speaker: Narrator

text: Or if I send a plague on that land, and with bloodshed I pour out my wrath on it to cut off man and beast from it,
speaker: Narrator

text: and if Noah, Daniel, and Job were in its midst, as I live, says the Lord God, they would not be able to save either their sons or their daughters. By their righteousness they would save only their own lives.
speaker: Narrator

text: For this is what the Lord God says. How much worse it will be when I send my four terrible judgments—sword, famine, wild animals, and plague—upon Jerusalem to cut off man and beast from it!
speaker: Narrator

text: But wait! A group of survivors will be left in it, those sons and daughters who will be brought out. Look! They are coming out to you, and you shall see their ways and their actions. Then you will be comforted concerning the disaster that I brought upon Jerusalem, everything that I brought upon it.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they will comfort you, because you will see their ways and their actions. Then you will know that it was not without cause that I did everything that I did against the city, declares the Lord God.
speaker: Narrator

text: The word of the Lord came to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Son of man, what can be done with the wood of a grapevine compared to the wood from the branches of all the other trees in the forest?
speaker: Narrator

text: Can its wood be used to make something useful? Can people make a peg from it to hang things on?
speaker: Narrator

text: No, it is fed into the fire for fuel. The fire devours both ends of it, and its middle is burned up. Is it useful for any purpose then?
speaker: Narrator

text: Since it could not be used for any purpose when it was undamaged, how much less can it be used to make anything useful after the fire has devoured it and it has been burned!
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, this is what the Lord says. Like the wood of the grapevine from among the trees of the forest, which I have fed into the fire for fuel, in the same way I will feed the inhabitants of Jerusalem into the fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will set my face against them. They have come out from the fire, but the fire will still devour them. Then you will know that I am the Lord when I set my face against them.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will make the land desolate because they added one infidelity to another, declares the Lord God.
speaker: Narrator

text: The word of the Lord came to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Son of man, confront Jerusalem with her abominations.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Tell them this is what the Lord God says to Jerusalem.
Your origin and your birth were from the land of the Canaanites. Your father was an Amorite and your mother a Hittite.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the way it was at your birth. On the day you were born, your umbilical cord was not cut, and you were not washed with water to clean you up. You were not rubbed down with salt, nor were you tightly wrapped with cloths.
speaker: Narrator

text: No eye looked at you with pity to do any of these things for you or to show compassion to you. On the day you were born, you were thrown out in the open field without regard for your life.
speaker: Narrator

text: I passed by, and I saw you squirming in your blood. I said to you, “You there, lying there in your blood, live!” and I said to you, “You there, lying there in your blood, live!”
speaker: Narrator

text: I made you grow like a sprout in the field. You grew up, you developed, and you became very beautiful. Your breasts were formed and your hair had appeared, but you were completely naked.
speaker: Narrator

text: I passed by and saw you, and I noticed that you were old enough for love. So I spread the skirt of my robe over you and covered your nakedness. I swore an oath to you to enter into a covenant of marriage with you, declares the Lord God, and you became mine.
speaker: Narrator

text: I washed you with water. I washed your blood off you. I anointed you with oil.
speaker: Narrator

text: I clothed you with the finest embroidered material and gave you sandals of luxurious leather. I wrapped your head in the best linen and covered you with silk.
speaker: Narrator

text: I adorned you with jewelry. I put bracelets on your wrists and a necklace around your neck.
speaker: Narrator

text: I put a ring on your nose, earrings on your ears, and a glorious crown on your head.
speaker: Narrator

text: So you were adorned with gold and silver, and your clothing was made of the best linen, with silk and the finest embroidered material. You ate fine flour, honey, and olive oil. You were extraordinarily beautiful, and you attained the status of a queen.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your fame spread throughout the nations because of your beauty. In fact, it was perfect because of my splendor, which I had bestowed upon you, declares the Lord God.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you trusted in your beauty, and, relying on your fame, you acted like a prostitute. You lavished your lust on every man passing by—you became his.
speaker: Narrator

text: You took some of your clothing and made colorful high places for yourself and acted like a prostitute on them. Such things should not happen. They should not be!
speaker: Narrator

text: You took your glorious articles made from my gold and my silver, which I had given to you, and you made male idols for yourself, and you acted like a prostitute with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: You took your clothing made of the finest embroidered material and covered the idols, and you set my oil and my incense in front of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also my food which I gave you—the fine flour, oil, and honey which I fed you—you set in front of them as a fragrant sacrifice. This is what happened, declares the Lord God.
speaker: Narrator

text: You even took your sons and your daughters, whom you bore for me, and sacrificed them as food for the idols. Was your continual prostitution not enough?
speaker: Narrator

text: Did you have to slaughter my children and offer them to the idols by making them pass through the fire?
speaker: Narrator

text: With all your abominations and your prostitution, you did not remember the days of your youth, when you were completely naked, when you were squirming about in your blood.
speaker: Narrator

text: So after all your wickedness—woe, woe to you, says the Lord God!—
speaker: Narrator

text: you built for yourself a platform, and you made a pavilion for yourself in every public square.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the corner of every street you set up your pavilion and made your beauty into a disgusting thing. You spread your legs for every man passing by, and you multiplied your acts of prostitution.
speaker: Narrator

text: You acted like a whore with the sons of Egypt, your neighbors with their enlarged flesh, and you multiplied your acts of prostitution to enrage me!
speaker: Narrator

text: Look at how I stretched out my hand against you. I reduced your territory. I gave you up to the desire of those who hate you, the daughters of the Philistines, who were embarrassed by your lewd ways.
speaker: Narrator

text: You acted like a whore with the sons of the Assyrians because you were insatiable. Even after your acts of prostitution with them, you were not satisfied.
speaker: Narrator

text: So you extended your whoring ways to the land of merchants, to Chaldea, but even with this you were not satisfied.
speaker: Narrator

text: How sick your heart is, says the Lord God, that you did all these things, the behavior of a woman who is a domineering whore!
speaker: Narrator

text: When you built your platform at the corner of every street and you made your pavilion in every public square, you were not like an ordinary prostitute, because you refused payment.
speaker: Narrator

text: You adulterous wife, who procures strange men instead of her husband,
speaker: Narrator

text: to all prostitutes men pay a fee, but you gave your gifts to all your lovers. You bribed them to come to you from all around to join your whoring ways.
speaker: Narrator

text: You were the opposite of the other women in your whoring ways. You were not solicited for prostitution, but you gave payment to your lovers. Instead of payment being given to you, you were the very opposite.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, you whore, hear the word of the Lord!
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Lord God says. Because your moisture was poured out, and your nakedness was exposed during your whoring ways with your lovers, because of all your disgusting, filthy idols, and because of the blood of your children, whom you gave to them,
speaker: Narrator

text: for all this, I am about to gather all your lovers to whom you were giving pleasure—all those you loved, as well as all those you hated. I will gather them against you from all around. I will expose your nakedness to them, and they will see your nakedness.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will judge you with the judgments deserved by women who commit adultery and who shed blood. I will make you bloody in my wrath and jealousy.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will deliver you into their hands, and they will tear down your platform, demolish your pavilion, strip you of your clothing, take away your glorious jewelry, and leave you completely naked.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will bring up a mob against you, and they will stone you and hack you to pieces with their swords.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will burn down your houses with fire and carry out judgments against you in the sight of many women. I will make you stop being a whore, and you will never again give a payment.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I will lay to rest my wrath against you, and my jealousy will turn away from you. I will be calm and no longer be angry.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because you did not remember the days of your youth, and you made me angry during all these actions, I myself will certainly bring your conduct down upon your head. That is the declaration of the Lord God! Haven’t you added lewdness to all your abominations?
speaker: Narrator

text: Hear this! Everyone will speak this proverb about you: “Like mother, like daughter.”
speaker: Narrator

text: You are a true daughter of your mother, who despises her husband and her children, and you are a true sister of your sisters, who despise their husbands and their children. The mother of all of you was a Hittite and your father was an Amorite.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your older sister is Samaria, who along with her daughters lives north of you, and your younger sister, who lives south of you along with her daughters, is Sodom.
speaker: Narrator

text: You did not merely walk in their ways or act according to their abominations, since in a very short time you became more depraved in all your ways than they were.
speaker: Narrator

text: As I live, says the Lord God, your sister Sodom along with her daughters has not done what you have done along with your daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Look, this was the guilt of your sister Sodom: Pride, overindulgence in food, and complacent ease were the way for her and her daughters, and she failed to strengthen the hands of the poor and needy.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were haughty, and they committed abominations in my presence, and so I removed them when I saw it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Samaria did not sin half as much as you did. You multiplied your abominations more than they did. You made your sisters appear righteous by all your abominations which you committed.
speaker: Narrator

text: So you must bear your disgrace, because by your sins you appeared to plead your sisters’ case for them. Because of your sins—you acted more repulsively than they did—they appear more righteous than you. So you must be ashamed and bear your disgrace, because you made your sisters appear righteous.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will bring about their restoration—the restoration of Sodom and her daughters, and the restoration of Samaria and her daughters, as well as your complete restoration in their midst,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that you will bear your disgrace, and you will be ashamed of everything you did when you appeared to give them comfort.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your sister Sodom and her daughters will return to their former state, and your sister Samaria and her daughters will return to their former state, and you and your daughters will return to your former state.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wasn’t your sister Sodom a subject for gossip in your mouth during the days when you were so proud,
speaker: Narrator

text: in the days before your own wickedness was exposed? So now in the same way you are subjected to scorn by the daughters of Edom and by all those around her and by the daughters of the Philistines, who scorn you from all sides.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your lewdness and your abominations, you must now bear, declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: So this is what the Lord God says. Shall I do with you just as you have done, you who despised your oath, thereby breaking the covenant?
speaker: Narrator

text: No, just the opposite, I myself will remember my covenant I made with you during the days of your youth, and I will establish an everlasting covenant for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you will remember your ways and be ashamed when you receive your sisters who are older than you, in addition to those who are younger than you, and I will give them to you as daughters, and not outside your covenant.
speaker: Narrator

text: I myself will establish my covenant with you. Then you will know that I am the Lord,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that you may remember and be ashamed and never again open your mouth because of your disgrace, when I make atonement for you for all that you have done, declares the Lord God.
speaker: Narrator

text: The word of the Lord came to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Son of man, present a challenging parable to the house of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Tell the Israelites that this is what the Lord God says.
A great eagle with powerful wings, with long feathers, and covered with multicolored plumes, came to Lebanon. He took the tip of a cedar.
speaker: Narrator

text: He plucked off the newest shoot at the very top of the tree, and he carried it to a land of merchants. In a city of traders he planted it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he took seed from the land and planted it in a fertile field, like a new plant beside plentiful water. He set it out like a willow twig,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that it would sprout and become a spreading vine, low to the ground, so that its branches would turn toward the one who planted it and its roots would remain under him. So it became a vine and produced shoots and leaves and branches.
speaker: Narrator

text: But there was another great eagle with powerful wings and many plumes. Look at how this vine bent its roots toward him! From the bed where it had been planted, it stretched out its branches toward him, so that he could water it.
speaker: Narrator

text: It had been planted in good soil beside plentiful water to grow branches, to bear fruit, and to become a magnificent vine.
speaker: Narrator

text: Tell them this is what the Lord God says. Will it thrive? Won’t he pull up its roots and strip off its fruit so that it dries up? Won’t all its new growth dry up? No strong arm or mighty army will be needed to pluck it by its roots.
speaker: Narrator

text: Although it has been planted, will it thrive? When the east wind touches it, won’t it shrivel up completely? On the very bed where it had sprouted, it will wither away.
speaker: Narrator

text: The word of the Lord came to me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Tell this to the rebellious house.
Don’t you know what these things mean? Tell them this. You saw how the king of Babylon came to Jerusalem. He took its king and its officials and brought them back to Babylon with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he took a member from the seed of the royal family, made a covenant with him, and put him under an oath. He took away the leading men of the land
speaker: Narrator

text: so that it would be a lowly kingdom, so that it would not rebel but would keep the covenant with him, so that it could survive.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the prince rebelled against that king by sending his envoys to Egypt to obtain horses and a large army. Will he thrive? Can someone who does such things escape? Can he break a covenant and still escape?
speaker: Narrator

text: As I live, says the Lord God, in the land of the king who made him king, whose oath he despised and whose covenant he broke, in his presence in Babylon, he shall die.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will not be joined by a mighty army or a great force during the war, because Pharaoh will not come when the enemy heaps up ramps and builds siege walls in order to cut off many lives.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king despised the oath by breaking the covenant. Even though he had given his hand to seal the covenant, he did all these things. He shall not escape!
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, this is what the Lord God says. As I live, because it was an oath taken in my name that the prince despised, I will bring down on his own head my covenant which he broke.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will spread my net for him, and he will be caught in my trap. I will bring him to Babylon, and I will enter into judgment with him there for the treachery he has committed against me.
speaker: Narrator

text: All his fugitives together with all his troops will fall by the sword, and the rest will be scattered to every wind. Then you will know that I, the Lord, have spoken.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Lord God says. I myself will take part of the tip of the cedar and plant it. From the topmost of its shoots I will pluck off a tender sprig, and I myself will plant it on a high and lofty mountain.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the high mountain of Israel I will plant it. It will produce branches, bear fruit, and become a magnificent cedar. Flying birds of every kind will live under it. In the shelter of its branches they will nest.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the trees in the countryside will know that I, the Lord, bring down the high tree and raise up the low tree, that I make the green tree dry up, and I make the dried-up tree blossom. I, the Lord, have spoken, and I will carry it out.
speaker: Narrator

text: The word of the Lord came to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: What do you mean, you who keep repeating this proverb concerning the soil of Israel, “Fathers eat sour grapes, and their sons’ teeth are set on edge”?
speaker: Narrator

text: As surely as I live, declares the Lord God, you will never again use this proverb in Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Indeed, all souls are mine. The soul of the father is mine just like the soul of the son. The soul who sins is the one who will die.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a man is righteous and practices justice and righteousness,
speaker: Narrator

text: if he does not eat on the mountains and does not lift up his eyes to the filthy idols of the house of Israel, if he does not defile his neighbor’s wife and does not approach a woman during her period,
speaker: Narrator

text: if he does not exploit anyone but returns the collateral given to him for a loan, if he does not seize another person’s property by force but gives his own food to the hungry and covers the naked with clothing,
speaker: Narrator

text: if he does not deduct a fee from the money he lends to someone and he does not demand that people repay more than he lent them, if he holds back his hand from unrighteousness and administers impartial justice between two parties,
speaker: Narrator

text: that is, if he walks in my statutes and keeps my ordinances by acting faithfully, that man is righteous and he will surely live, declares the Lord God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now if he fathers a violent son, who sheds blood or who does any one of these evil things to a brother
speaker: Narrator

text: (although the father did not do all these things), but the son goes so far as to eat on the mountains and even defiles his neighbor’s wife,
speaker: Narrator

text: exploits the poor and the needy, seizes other people’s property by force, does not return the collateral on a loan, lifts up his eyes to the filthy idols, commits abominations,
speaker: Narrator

text: and deducts a fee from the money he lends to someone and demands that people repay more than he lent them—will he live? He will not live! He committed all these abominations, so he will surely be put to death. His blood will be upon him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if that son himself fathers a son who sees all the sins that his father has committed, and though he sees, he does not do likewise—
speaker: Narrator

text: he does not eat on the mountains, he does not lift up his eyes to the filthy idols of the house of Israel, he does not defile his neighbor’s wife,
speaker: Narrator

text: he does not exploit anyone, he does not require collateral for a loan, he does not seize another person’s property by force, he gives his own food to the hungry and he covers the naked with clothing,
speaker: Narrator

text: he takes care not to harm the poor, he does not deduct a fee from the money he lends someone or demand that people repay more than he lent them, but he keeps my ordinances and walks according to my statutes—that man will not die because of his father’s guilt. He will surely live.
speaker: Narrator

text: But his father, if he practices extortion, seizes his brother’s goods by force, and does what was not good among his own people, he will surely die because of his own guilt.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you ask, “Why doesn’t the son share in the guilt of the father?” Because the son did what was just and right. He kept all my statutes and carried them out, so he will surely live.
speaker: Narrator

text: The soul who sins is the one who will die. The son will not share in the guilt of the father, and the father will not share in the guilt of the son. The righteousness of the righteous person will be credited to him alone, and the wickedness of the wicked person will be charged against him alone.
speaker: Narrator

text: A wicked man, if he turns away from all his sins that he has committed and keeps all my statutes and carries out justice and righteousness, he will surely live. He will not die.
speaker: Narrator

text: All of the rebellious acts that he had committed will not be remembered against him. Because of his righteousness that he has practiced, he will live.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do I really find any pleasure in the death of the wicked? says the Lord God. Don’t I want him to turn from his ways and live?
speaker: Narrator

text: But if a righteous man turns away from his righteousness and does what is unrighteous—namely, all the abominations that the wicked man practices—will he live? All the righteous deeds that he did will not be remembered. Because he added one infidelity to another and because of the sins that he has committed, because of them, he will die.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you say, “The Lord’s way is not fair.” Listen now, house of Israel. Is it my way that is not fair? Is it not your ways that are not fair?
speaker: Narrator

text: If a righteous man turns away from his righteousness and practices unrighteousness, he will die because of it. Because of the unrighteousness that he has practiced, he will die.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if a wicked man turns from his wickedness that he has done and practices justice and righteousness, he will preserve his life.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because he has seen and turned away from all the rebellious acts that he had committed, he will surely live, and he will not die.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the house of Israel says, “The Lord’s way is not fair.” Is it really my ways that are not fair, O house of Israel? Is it not your ways that are not fair?
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, I will judge each one of you according to his ways, O house of Israel, declares the Lord God. Repent and turn away from all your rebellious acts, so that you will not set out a stumbling block that makes you guilty.
speaker: Narrator

text: Throw off from yourselves all your rebellious actions by which you have rebelled, and obtain a new heart and a new spirit for yourselves. Why should you die, O house of Israel?
speaker: Narrator

text: For I take no pleasure in the death of anyone who dies, declares the Lord God. So repent and live!
speaker: Narrator

text: Now you are to take up a lament for the princes of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is what you are to say:
    What a lioness your mother was!
    She crouched among the lions.
    Among the young lions she reared her cubs.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She raised up one of her cubs.
    When he became a young lion,
        he learned to tear his prey.
    He even ate humans.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the nations heard about him,
        he was trapped in their pit.
    With hooks they led him to the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When she saw that she was waiting in vain,
    that her hope was lost,
        she took another of her cubs
        and made him a young lion.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He prowled around among the lions,
    because he too had become a young lion.
    He learned to tear prey.
    He even ate humans.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He knew how many widows he made
        as he ravaged their cities.
    The land and everyone in it were stunned
        by the noise of his roaring.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Nations set upon him from the surrounding provinces.
    They spread their net over him,
    and he was trapped in their pit.
speaker: Narrator

text:
With hooks they put him in a wooden cage,
    and they brought him to the king of Babylon.
    They brought him into prison
