        so that his roar would no longer be heard
        on the mountains of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your mother was like a vine in your vineyard,
    planted by water, fruitful and full of branches
    because of plentiful waters.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Its strong branches became scepters for rulers.
    It towered high, among the clouds.
    It was outstanding because of its height,
    and because of the abundance of its branches.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But the vine was uprooted in wrath,
    and it was hurled to the ground.
    The east wind dried up its fruit.
    Its strong branch was torn off so that it dried up,
    and fire devoured it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now it is planted in the wilderness,
    in a dry and thirsty land.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Fire has come out from its main branch
    and consumed its fruit,
    so that it no longer has a strong branch,
    no scepter fit for ruling.
This is a lament, and it was used as a lament.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the seventh year, in the fifth month, on the tenth day of the month, men came from the elders of Israel to consult the Lord, and they sat down in front of me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the word of the Lord came to me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Son of man, speak to the elders of Israel and tell them this.”
This is what the Lord God says to them:
Are you really coming to consult me? As I live, I will not let myself be consulted by you, declares the Lord God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Will you put them on trial? Will you put them on trial, son of man? Remind them of the abominable practices of their fathers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You are to tell them the following.
This is what the Lord God says. On the day when I chose Israel, when I swore with an uplifted hand to the descendants of the house of Jacob, when I made myself known to them in the land of Egypt, then I lifted up my hand to them in an oath. I said, “I am the Lord, your God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day I swore to them with an uplifted hand to bring them out of the land of Egypt to a land that I had searched out for them, a land flowing with milk and honey. It was the most glorious of all the lands.
speaker: Narrator

text: I said to them, “Each man must throw away the loathsome things he sets his eyes on. You must not defile yourselves with the filthy idols of Egypt. I am the Lord, your God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But they rebelled against me and were not willing to listen to me. Not one of them threw away the loathsome things which they set their eyes on. They did not forsake the filthy idols of Egypt, so I resolved to pour out my wrath on them and to exhaust my anger against them in the middle of the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: I acted for the sake of my name, so that it would not be profaned in the sight of the nations that were around them, the nations in whose sight I had made myself known by bringing the Israelites out of the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I brought them out of the land of Egypt and led them into the wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text: I gave them my statutes, and I made my ordinances known to them, ordinances by which a man will live if he observes them.
speaker: Narrator

text: I also gave them my Sabbaths to be a sign between me and them, so that they could know that I, the Lord, am the one who sanctifies them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the house of Israel rebelled against me in the wilderness. They did not walk in my statutes, and they rejected my ordinances (ordinances by which a man will live if he observes them), and they profaned my Sabbaths completely. So I threatened to pour out my wrath on them in the wilderness in order to annihilate them.
speaker: Narrator

text: I acted for the sake of my name, so that it would not be profaned in the sight of the nations in whose sight I had brought them out from Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: I also swore to them with an uplifted hand in the wilderness that I would not bring them into the land that I had given to them, a land flowing with milk and honey—it is the most glorious of all the lands—
speaker: Narrator

text: because they rejected my ordinances and did not walk in my statutes. Instead, they profaned my Sabbaths. This happened because their hearts chase after their filthy idols.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nevertheless, my eye had pity on them so that I did not destroy them, and I did not completely destroy them in the wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I said to their children in the wilderness: “Do not walk in the statutes of your fathers. Do not observe their ordinances, and do not defile yourselves with their filthy idols.
speaker: Narrator

text: I, the Lord, am your God. Walk in my statutes, and observe my ordinances and practice them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Keep my Sabbaths holy so that they may be a sign between me and you, so that you may know that I, the Lord, am your God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the children too rebelled against me. They did not walk in my statutes. They did not observe my ordinances by practicing them, statutes by which a person will live if he observes them. They profaned my Sabbaths, so I resolved to pour out my wrath on them and to exhaust my anger on them in the wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nevertheless, I held back my hand and acted for the sake of my name, so that it would not be profaned in the sight of the nations in whose sight I had brought them out from Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, I raised my hand in an oath to them in the wilderness and swore that I would scatter them among the nations and disperse them among the countries
speaker: Narrator

text: because they had not observed my ordinances. They despised my statutes. They profaned my Sabbaths, and they fixed their eyes on the filthy idols of their fathers.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I gave them statutes that were not good and ordinances by which they could not live.
speaker: Narrator

text: I defiled them through their sacrificial gifts—when they made all their firstborn pass through the fire—in order to devastate them, so that they would know that I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore, speak to the house of Israel, son of man, and tell them this.
This is what the Lord God says. In this too your fathers blasphemed me by committing infidelity after infidelity against me.
speaker: Narrator

text: When I brought them to the land which I had sworn with an uplifted hand to give to them, whenever they saw any high hill or any leafy tree, they offered their sacrifices there. There they placed their offerings that provoke me. There they offered their fragrant sacrifices. There they poured out their drink offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I said to them, “What is the high place to which you are going?” So it is called Bamah to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore, say this to the house of Israel.
This is what the Lord God says. Are you continuing to defile yourselves in the way your fathers did? Are you still whoring after their loathsome idolatries?
speaker: Narrator

text: When you offer your gifts and make your sons pass through the fire, you continue to defile yourselves by all your filthy idols to this day. So should I let myself be consulted by you, house of Israel? As I live, says the Lord God, I will not let myself be consulted by you.
speaker: Narrator

text: What you have in mind will definitely never take place. You are saying, “Let us become like the nations, like the clans in other countries, by worshipping wood and stone.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As I live, says the Lord God, with a mighty hand, with an outstretched arm, and with wrath outpoured, I will rule over you!
speaker: Narrator

text: I will bring you out from the nations, and I will gather you from the countries among which you have been scattered. With a mighty hand, with an outstretched arm, and with wrath outpoured,
speaker: Narrator

text: I will bring you into the wilderness of the peoples. There I will enter into judgment with you face-to-face.
speaker: Narrator

text: As I entered into judgment with your fathers in the wilderness of the land of Egypt, so will I enter into judgment with you, declares the Lord God.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will make you pass under the rod, and I will bring you under the binding terms of the covenant.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will purge out from among you those who revolt and rebel against me. From the land where they are staying I will bring them out, but they shall not come into the land of Israel. Then you will know that I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: But to you, house of Israel, this is what the Lord God says. Let each man go and worship his filthy idols, but after that, even if you will not listen to me, you will no longer profane my holy name with your gifts and with your filthy idols.
speaker: Narrator

text: For on my holy mountain, on the high mountain of Israel, declares the Lord God, the whole house of Israel will worship me there—the whole nation in its homeland. There I will accept them. There I will request your offerings and your special gifts together with all your holy things.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will accept you as a fragrant sacrifice when I bring you out from the nations and when I gather you from the lands among which you were scattered. Then through you, I will show that I am holy in the sight of the nations.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will know that I am the Lord when I bring you back to the soil of Israel, to the land that I swore with an upraised hand to give to your fathers.
speaker: Narrator

text: There you will remember your ways and all your deeds by which you defiled yourselves, and you will despise yourselves for all your evil deeds which you have done.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you will know that I am the Lord, when I deal with you for the sake of my name and not according to your evil ways and your corrupt deeds, O house of Israel, declares the Lord God.
speaker: Narrator

text: The word of the Lord came to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Son of man, set your face toward Teman. Preach against the Southland, and prophesy against the scrubby forest in the Negev.
speaker: Narrator

text: Say this to the scrub forest in the Negev. Hear the word of the Lord! This is what the Lord God says. I am about to ignite a fire among you, and among you it will devour every green tree and every dry tree. The blazing flame will not be extinguished. Every face will be scorched by it, from south to north.
speaker: Narrator

text: All flesh will see that I, the Lord, have ignited it. It will not be extinguished.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I said, “Oh, Lord God, they are saying about me, ‘Doesn’t he just talk in puzzling parables?’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The word of the Lord came to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Son of man, set your face toward Jerusalem. Preach against the sanctuaries, and prophesy against the land of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Say this to the land of Israel.
This is what the Lord says. Hear this! I am against you, and I will draw my sword out of its scabbard, and I will cut off from you both the righteous and the wicked.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because I have resolved to cut off from you both the righteous and the wicked, therefore my sword will come out of its scabbard against everyone from south to north.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all flesh will know that I, the Lord, have drawn my sword from its scabbard. It will not return to its sheath again.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now you, son of man, groan as though you were doubled up in pain. Groan in front of them as though in bitter anguish.

text: Now the coastlands tremble on the day of your downfall. The coastlands that are on the sea are terrified by your collapse.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So this is what the Lord God says. When I make you a ruined city like the cities that are not inhabited, when I bring up the deep over you and the many waters cover you,
speaker: Narrator

text: then I will bring you down to be with those who have descended to the pit, to the people from ancient times. I will make you live below the earth, like ancient ruins. You will be with those who have descended to the pit, so that you will be uninhabited, and I will not give you glory in the land of the living.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will make you an object of horror, and you will no longer exist. You will be sought but never found again, declares the Lord God.
speaker: Narrator

text: The word of the Lord came to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: You, son of man, take up a lament over Tyre.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Tell Tyre, who dwells at the entrances to the sea as a merchant traveling to many coastlands, this is what the Lord God says.
    Tyre, you say, “I am a perfect beauty.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your borders were in the heart of the sea.
    Your builders perfected your beauty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They built for you a double-decked ship, made of fir from Senir.
    They took a cedar from Lebanon to make a mast for you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They made your oars of oak from Bashan.
    Your planks were made of pine, inlaid with ivory,
        from the coasts of Cyprus.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your sail was brightly decorated linen from Egypt,
    which also served as your banner.
    Your awning was blue and purple from the coasts of Elishah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Inhabitants of Sidon and Arvad served as your rowers.
    Tyre, your own skilled men, who were with you,
        manned your sails.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Skilled veterans from Gebal were on board with you,
        serving as your repairmen.
    All the ships of the sea and their sailors
        were in your harbor to engage in trade with you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Warriors from Persia, Lud, and Put were in your army.
    They hung up their shields and helmets among you.
    They enhanced your splendor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Men of Arvad and Cilicia were on your walls all around,
    and men of Gammad were on your towers.
    They hung their quivers all around on your walls.
    They made your beauty perfect.
speaker: Narrator

text: Tarshish traded with you because of your great wealth of every kind. They traded silver, iron, tin, and lead for your exports.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ionia, Tubal, and Meshek also dealt with you. They traded human beings and articles of bronze for your wares.
speaker: Narrator

text: From Beth Togarmah, horses, war horses, and mules were traded to you because of the abundance of your products.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of Rhodes also dealt with you. Many coastlands were agents of your trade, bringing back ivory tusks and ebony in payment to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Edom traded with you because of the abundance of your products. They sold turquoise, purple, and finely embroidered cloth, linen, coral, and rubies to you as exports.
speaker: Narrator

text: Judah and the land of Israel also dealt with you. With wheat of Minnith, flour, honey, oil, and balm they bought your wares.
speaker: Narrator

text: Damascus traded with you because of the abundance of your products, because of the abundance of all kinds of wealth. They sold wine of Helbon, wool from Sahar,
speaker: Narrator

text: and wine casks from Izalla as exports. Wrought iron, cassia, and calamus were traded for your goods.
speaker: Narrator

text: Dedan traded to you saddle blankets used for riding.
speaker: Narrator

text: Arabia and all the rulers of Kedar were your agents for trade in lambs, rams, and goats. They were your agents for those.
speaker: Narrator

text: Merchants of Sheba and Ra’amah dealt with you in all kinds of expensive perfumes and in all kinds of precious stones and gold, which they sold you for your merchandise.
speaker: Narrator

text: Haran, Kanneh, and Eden, and dealers from Sheba, Assyria, and Kilmad were your dealers.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were your dealers in elegant clothing, in purple garments and finely embroidered cloth, in carpets with multicolored trim, tightly wound with ropes for your marketplaces.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Tarshish ships traveled for you with your merchandise.
So you were full and very heavily loaded in the midst of the seas.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your rowers brought you out into deep water. An east wind broke you up in the heart of the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your wealth, your exports and your imports, your sailors and your pilots, your repairmen, and those who bring you imports, all your warriors on board—in fact, all your company who were on board—will sink into the heart of the sea on the day of your collapse.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the sound of the cry of distress from your pilots, the fields on the mainland will quake.
speaker: Narrator

text: All who handle the oars will abandon their ships. The sailors and all the pilots of the sea will stand on shore.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will shout loudly because of you and cry out bitterly. They will throw dirt on their heads and roll in ashes.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will make themselves bald on account of you and put on sackcloth. They will weep bitterly over you, with a bitter lament.
speaker: Narrator

text: In their grief, they will raise a lament over you. They utter this lament over you, “Who is like Tyre, now silenced in the midst of the sea?”
speaker: Narrator

text: When your exports were unloaded from the seas, you satisfied many peoples. By your abundant wealth and your imports, you enriched the kings of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now you have been broken up by the seas and sunk into the watery depths. Your merchandise and the entire company on board have sunk.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the inhabitants of the coastlands are appalled because of you. Their kings’ hair stands on end. Their faces show distress.
speaker: Narrator

text: Traders among the peoples whistle and hiss at you. You have become horrifying, and you will never exist again, forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: The word of the Lord came to me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Son of man, say to the prince of Tyre that this is what the Lord God says.
Because you became arrogant and said, “I am a god, and I occupy a throne of a god in the heart of the seas,” even though you are a mere man and not a god, and because you regard your wisdom as divine wisdom—
speaker: Narrator

text: You really think you are wiser than Daniel, don’t you? No mystery baffles you.
speaker: Narrator

text: By your wisdom and your shrewdness you have gained wealth for yourself and put gold and silver into your treasuries.
speaker: Narrator

text: By your great skill in trading, you increased your wealth, but you became conceited because of your wealth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, this is what the Lord God says. Because you regard your wisdom as divine wisdom,
speaker: Narrator

text: therefore, I am about to bring foreigners against you, the most ruthless of nations. They will unsheathe their swords against your beautiful wisdom, and they will desecrate your radiant splendor.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will cast you down to the pit, and you will die a violent death in the heart of the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: Will you still claim “I am a god” in the presence of the one who kills you? It will be clear that you are merely a man and not a god when you fall into the hands of those who run you through.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will die a death like that of the uncircumcised by the hand of foreigners, for I have spoken, declares the Lord God.
speaker: Narrator

text: The word of the Lord came to me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Son of man, raise a lament over the king of Tyre. Say to him that this is what the Lord God says.
You were a seal of perfection, full of wisdom, and perfect in beauty.
speaker: Narrator

text: You were in Eden, the garden of God. Every kind of precious stone was covering you: carnelian, diamond, emerald, topaz, onyx, jasper, sapphire, agate, and beryl. Your mountings and your settings were worked in gold. They were prepared on the day you were created.
speaker: Narrator

text: You were a cherub, the anointed guardian. I appointed you. You were on the holy mountain of God, and you walked about in the midst of sparkling stones.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your conduct was blameless from the day you were created until guilt was found in you.
speaker: Narrator

text: In your widespread trade, you practiced much violence and you sinned. I defiled you by banishing you from the mountain of God. I expelled you, you guardian cherub, from among the sparkling stones.
speaker: Narrator

text: You became arrogant because of your beauty, and you corrupted your wisdom together with your splendor. So I hurled you down to the earth and set you in front of kings who gloated over you.
speaker: Narrator

text: By your many sins during your unscrupulous trade, you defiled your sanctuaries. So I made fire break out from your midst, and it devoured you. I reduced you to ashes on the ground in the sight of all who were watching.
speaker: Narrator

text: All those among the people who knew you are appalled at you. You have become horrifying, and you will never exist again, forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: The word of the Lord came to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Son of man, set your face toward Sidon, and prophesy against her.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Say that this is what the Lord God says.
I am against you, Sidon. I will display my glory in your midst, and they will know that I am the Lord, when I inflict punishments on you and display my holiness in you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will release the plague in her. There will be blood in her streets, and the slain will fall in her midst when the sword comes against her from all sides. Then they will know that I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Never again will the house of Israel be subjected to those who deride them, who are all around them like prickly briers or painful thorns. Then they will know that I am the Lord God.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Lord God says. When I gather the house of Israel from the peoples where they have been scattered, I will display my holiness through them in the sight of the nations. Then they will live on their own land, which I gave to my servant Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will live on it in security. They will build houses and plant vineyards. They will live on it in security when I inflict judgments upon all those around them who despise them. Then they will know that I am the Lord, their God.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the tenth year in the tenth month, on the twelfth day of the month, the word of the Lord came to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Son of man, set your face against Pharaoh, the king of Egypt, and prophesy against him and against all Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Speak and tell them that this is what the Lord God says.
I am against you, Pharaoh, king of Egypt, the great monster who stretches out in the channels of the Nile. You say, “It is my Nile. I made it for myself.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But I, the Lord, will put hooks in your jaws and make the fish of your Nile stick to your scales. I will haul you up from the middle of your Nile with all the fish from the Nile clinging to your scales.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will leave you in the wilderness—you and all the fish of your Nile. You will lie fallen on the surface of the ground. You will not be collected or gathered up. I will give you as food to the wild animals of the earth and to the birds of the air.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then all the inhabitants of Egypt will know that I am the Lord.
For the house of Israel, the Egyptians have been a staff made out of a reed.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Israel grasped you with their hands, you would splinter and tear open all their shoulders. When they leaned on you, you would break and make them lose their balance.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, this is what the Lord God says: I am about to bring a sword against you and cut off man and beast from you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The land of Egypt will become a desolate ruin, and they will know that I am the Lord.
Because he said, “It is my Nile. I made it for myself,”
speaker: Narrator

text: therefore, I am against you and against the channels of your Nile. I will turn the land of Egypt into ruins, a parched desolation—from Migdol to Aswan, that is, up to the border with Cush.
speaker: Narrator

text: No one will set foot in it. No animal will set foot in it. It will remain uninhabited for forty years.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will make the land of Egypt more desolate than any other land, and its cities will be the most desolate of ruined cities for forty years. I will scatter the Egyptians among the nations and disperse them among the countries.
speaker: Narrator

text: Furthermore, this is what the Lord God says. At the end of forty years, I will gather the Egyptians from among the peoples where they were scattered.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will bring about the restoration of Egypt and return them to Upper Egypt, the land of their origin, and there they will be a lowly kingdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: It will be the lowliest of kingdoms, and it will never again exalt itself above other nations. I will make it so weak that it will never again rule over the nations.
speaker: Narrator

text: It will never again be a source of trust for the house of Israel. It will be a reminder of their guilt when they turned to Egypt for help. Then they will know that I am the Lord God.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the twenty-seventh year, in the first month, on the first day of the month, the word of the Lord came to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Son of man, Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon made his army labor hard against Tyre. Every head was made bald, and every shoulder rubbed raw, yet neither he nor his army received any reward for the labor they had expended against Tyre.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, this is what the Lord God says. I am about to give the land of Egypt to Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon. He will carry off its wealth, plunder it, and pillage it. That will be the reward for his army.
speaker: Narrator

text: As his pay for which he labored, I have given him the land of Egypt, because his army did it for me, declares the Lord God.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day I will make a horn sprout for the house of Israel, and I will open your mouth among them. Then they will know that I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The word of the Lord came to me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Son of man, prophesy and say, “This is what the Lord God says.”
All of you, wail! What a miserable day!
speaker: Narrator

text: Yes, that day is near. The Day of the Lord is near. It will be a day of clouds, a time for the nations.
speaker: Narrator

text: A sword will enter Egypt, and there will be anguish in Cush when the slain fall in Egypt. Then they will take away its wealth, and its foundations will be demolished.
speaker: Narrator

text: Cush, Put, Lud, and all the other mercenaries, Libya and the men from the land of the covenant will fall by the sword along with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Lord says. Those who prop up Egypt will fall, and its proud power will sink down. From Migdol to Aswan, those in Egypt will fall by the sword, declares the Lord God.
speaker: Narrator

text: It will be the most desolate among the desolate lands, and its cities will be the most ruined among the ruined cities.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will know that I am the Lord when I set fire to Egypt, and all its helpers are crushed.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day, messengers will go out from me in ships to terrify confident Cush, and there will be panic among them on the day for Egypt, for it is surely coming.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Lord God says. I will put an end to the horde of Egypt by the hand of Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text: He and his army with him, the most ruthless of nations, will be brought in to destroy the land. They will unsheathe their swords against Egypt and fill the land with the fallen.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will dry up the channels of the Nile and sell the land to evil men. I will devastate the land and everything in it by the hand of foreigners. I, the Lord, have spoken.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Lord God says. I will destroy the filthy idols and eliminate from Memphis the gods that are not gods. There will no longer be a ruler in the land of Egypt, and I will put fear into the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will desolate Upper Egypt. I will set fire to Zoan and inflict punishments on Thebes.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will pour out my wrath on Pelusium, the stronghold of Egypt, and I will cut off the horde of Thebes.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will set fire to Egypt. Pelusium will writhe in pain. The defenses of Thebes will be broken down, and Memphis will face enemies every day.
speaker: Narrator

text: The young men of Heliopolis and Bubastis will fall by the sword, and the women will go into captivity.
speaker: Narrator

text: At Tahpanhes the day will grow dark when I break the yokes of Egypt there, and there its proud power will cease. A cloud will cover it, and its daughters will go into captivity.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will inflict judgment on Egypt. Then they will know that I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the eleventh year, in the first month, on the seventh day of the month, the word of the Lord came to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Son of man, I have broken the arm of Pharaoh, the king of Egypt. But it has not been wrapped up so that it can heal. It has not been wrapped tightly with a splint to help it heal, so that it can become strong enough to grasp a sword.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, this is what the Lord God says. I am against Pharaoh, the king of Egypt, and I will break his arms, both the strong one and the one that was broken, and in this way I will cause the sword to fall from his hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will scatter Egypt among the nations and disperse them among the countries.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will strengthen the arms of the king of Babylon and put my sword into his hand. But I will break the arms of Pharaoh, and he will groan in the presence of the king of Babylon with groans like someone who is mortally wounded.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will strengthen the arms of the king of Babylon, but the arms of Pharaoh will hang limp. They will know that I am the Lord when I put my sword into the hand of the king of Babylon, and he stretches it out against the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will scatter Egypt among the nations and disperse them among the countries. Then they will know that I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the eleventh year, in the third month, on the first day of the month, the word of the Lord came to me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Son of man, say this to Pharaoh, the king of Egypt, and to his horde.
To whom can you be compared in your greatness?
speaker: Narrator

text: Consider Assyria. It was a cedar in Lebanon. It had beautiful branches, which gave shade to the woodland. It was very tall, and its top reached to the clouds.
speaker: Narrator

text: The waters made it grow. The deep springs made it tall, sending out rivers which flowed around the spot where it was planted, and they sent smaller ditches out to all the other trees in the countryside.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the cedar was taller than all the other trees in the countryside. It produced many branches, and its boughs grew long, because of the plentiful water when it sent out shoots.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the birds in the sky nested in its boughs. All the wild animals in the countryside gave birth under its branches, and all the mighty nations lived in its shade.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was beautiful in its grandeur and in the length of its branches, because its roots reached down to plentiful water.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even the cedars in the garden of God did not overshadow it. The boughs of the fir trees were not equal to its boughs, and the chestnut tree could not rival its many branches. No tree in the garden of God could equal it in beauty.
speaker: Narrator

text: I made it so beautiful by the abundance of its branches that all the trees of Eden that were in the garden of God envied it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, this is what the Lord God says. Because you were so tall, because the cedar stretched its top up between the clouds, and its heart became haughty because of its height,
speaker: Narrator

text: I will hand it over to a chief of nations, and he will deal harshly with it. I banished it as its wickedness deserved.
speaker: Narrator

text: Foreigners, the most ruthless of nations, cut it down and discarded it. Its branches fell on the mountains and in all the valleys. Its boughs lay broken in all the streambeds of the land, and all the peoples of the earth left its shade and abandoned it.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the birds in the sky lodged on its fallen trunk, and all the wild animals in the countryside came to its branches.
speaker: Narrator

text: All this happened so that all the well-watered trees would never again reach such heights or stretch their tops up between the clouds. Nor will the tallest of them remain standing—even though they drink in water—because they have all been handed over to death, to be below the earth, along with all mankind, with those who have descended to the pit.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Lord God says. When Assyria went down to the grave, I caused mourning everywhere. I covered the deep because of it. I restrained the rivers of the deep, and the plentiful waters were held back. I dressed Lebanon in black because of it, and all the trees in the countryside dried up because of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: I made the nations quake at the sound of its fall, when I brought it down to the grave to be with those who have descended to the pit. Below the earth, all the trees of Eden, the choicest and best of Lebanon, all those that drink up water, consoled themselves,
speaker: Narrator

text: even those who served as Assyria’s arm, those who lived in its shade among the nations, even those who went down to the grave with it, those run through by the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text: To whom, then, can you be compared in glory and greatness among the trees of Eden? Yet you shall be brought down below the earth, together with the trees of Eden. You shall lie among the uncircumcised, together with those run through by the sword. This is Pharaoh and all his horde, declares the Lord God.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the twelfth year, in the twelfth month, on the first day of the month, the word of the Lord came to me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Son of man, raise a lament over Pharaoh, the king of Egypt, and say this to him.
You consider yourself a young lion among the nations, but you are like a monster in the seas. You thrash around in your rivers. You churn up the water with your feet and make the rivers muddy.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Lord God says. I will cast my net over you by an array of mighty nations, and they will haul you up in my fishing net.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will haul you up and leave you on dry land and throw you into an open field. I will let all the birds of the air settle on you. I will let all the wild animals of the earth feed on you till they are filled.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will dump your flesh on the mountains and fill the ravines with your carcass.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will drench the land with the overflow of your blood, up to the mountains, and the streambeds will be filled with your remains.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you are snuffed out, I will cover the sky and darken its stars. I will cover the sun with a cloud, and the moon will not give its light.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will black out all the bright lights in the sky because of you. I will bring darkness over your land, declares the Lord God.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will disturb the hearts of mighty peoples when I bring word about your downfall to the nations, to countries you do not know.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will make many peoples appalled by you, and their kings’ hair will stand on end because of you, when I brandish my sword in front of them. They will tremble every minute, each for his own life, on the day when you fall.
speaker: Narrator

text: For this is what the Lord God says. The sword of the king of Babylon will come against you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will cut down your horde by the swords of his warriors, all of them from the most ruthless of nations. They will devastate the pride of Egypt, and its whole horde will be exterminated.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will kill all its livestock beside many waters. No human foot will ever muddy the waters again, nor will the hoofs of cattle ever muddy them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I will let their waters settle and become clear and will make their channels flow like oil, declares the Lord God.
speaker: Narrator

text: When I cause the land of Egypt to be deserted, when the land is emptied of everything that filled it, when I have struck down all its inhabitants, then they will know that I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is a lament, which they will wail. The daughters of the nations will wail it. Over Egypt and all its horde they will wail it, declares the Lord God.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the twelfth year, on the fifteenth day of the month, the word of the Lord came to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Son of man, mourn over the horde of Egypt and send her down below the earth with the daughters of majestic nations, to be with those who have descended to the pit.
speaker: Narrator

text: Are you more favored than others? Go on down and lie down among the uncircumcised.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will fall among those who were run through by the sword. A sword has been appointed. Egypt and all its hordes will be carried off.
speaker: Narrator

text: The elite warriors will speak to him and to his allies from the midst of the grave. The uncircumcised, those run through by the sword, have come down and lie there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Assyria is there with her whole crowd. Their graves are around her. All of them are slain, fallen by the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text: Her graves are set in the deepest part of the pit, and her crowd is all around her grave, all of them slain, fallen by the sword, all those who once spread terror in the land of the living.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elam is there, with her whole horde around her grave, all of them slain, fallen by the sword, those who went down below the earth uncircumcised, those who once spread terror in the land of the living. They bear their shame along with those who have descended to the pit.
speaker: Narrator

text: A bed is made for Elam among the slain, with its whole horde around its graves, all of them uncircumcised, run through by the sword. Because they once spread terror in the land of the living, they will bear their shame with those who have descended to the pit. They are placed among the slain.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meshek Tubal is there with its whole horde around its graves, all of them uncircumcised, run through by the sword because they had spread terror in the land of the living.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do they not lie with other fallen, uncircumcised warriors, who went down to the grave with their weapons of war, with their swords placed under their heads, with evidence of their guilt on their bones, because of the terror these warriors had once spread in the land of the living?
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh, you too will be broken in the midst of the uncircumcised and will lie with those run through by the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text: Edom is there, with its kings and all its chiefs, who, despite their strength, are placed with those run through by the sword. They lie with the uncircumcised, with those who have descended to the pit.
speaker: Narrator

text: The princes of the north are there, all of them, and every Sidonian, who went down with the slain despite the terror they had caused. Their strength failed them. They lie uncircumcised with those run through by the sword, and they bear their shame along with those who have descended to the pit.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh will see them all and will console himself concerning his whole horde. Pharaoh is run through by the sword with his whole army, declares the Lord God.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I have set my terror in the land of the living, and he will be forced to lie down among the uncircumcised, with those run through by the sword, that is, Pharaoh and his whole horde, declares the Lord God.
speaker: Narrator

text: The word of the Lord came to me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Son of man, speak to your countrymen and say this to them.
When I bring a sword against a land, and the people of the land appoint one man from their midst as their watchman,
speaker: Narrator

text: and that man sees the sword coming upon the land and blows the ram’s horn to warn the people,
speaker: Narrator

text: then if anyone who hears the sound of the ram’s horn does not heed the warning, and as a result the sword comes and takes him away, his blood will be on his own head.
speaker: Narrator

text: He heard the sound of the ram’s horn, but he did not take warning, so his own blood is on him. If he had heeded the warning, he would have saved his life.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if the watchman sees the sword coming but does not blow the ram’s horn, and as a result the people are not warned, then if the sword comes and takes one of them away, that man has been taken away because of his own guilt, but I will also hold the watchman responsible for his blood.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I have appointed you, son of man, to be a watchman for the house of Israel. So whenever you hear a word from my mouth, you are to warn them from me.
speaker: Narrator

text: When I say to a wicked man, “Wicked man, you shall surely die,” if you do not speak to warn the wicked man against his way, that wicked man will die because of his guilt, but I will also hold you responsible for his blood.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you do warn the wicked man to turn from his way, and he does not turn from his way, he will die because of his guilt, but you will have saved your life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So you, son of man, say the following to the house of Israel.
This is what you people are saying: “Certainly our rebellion and our sins weigh us down, and because of them we are rotting away. How then can we live?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Say to them, “As I live, declares the Lord God, I take no pleasure in the death of the wicked, but rather that the wicked turn from their way and live. Turn back, turn back from your evil ways, for why should you die, O house of Israel?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So you, son of man, also say this to your countrymen.
The righteousness of a righteous man will not save him on the day that he rebels, and the wickedness of a wicked man will not cause him to stumble on the day that he turns away from his wickedness. Likewise, a righteous man will not be able to live by his righteousness on the day that he sins.
speaker: Narrator

text: When I say about the righteous man, “He will surely live,” but he then trusts in his own righteousness and does unrighteous things, all of his righteous acts will no longer be remembered, and he will die because of the unrighteous things he does.
speaker: Narrator

text: Or when I say to the wicked man, “You will surely die,” and he turns from his sin and practices justice and righteousness—
speaker: Narrator

text: if that wicked man returns the collateral paid to him for a loan, returns what he has stolen, walks in the laws that lead to life, and so avoids doing unrighteous things—he will surely live. He will not die.
speaker: Narrator

text: All of the evil acts he committed will not be remembered against him. Since he has practiced justice and righteousness, he will certainly live.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet, your countrymen are saying, “The Lord’s way is not fair,” although it is actually their way that is not fair.
speaker: Narrator

text: When a righteous man turns away from his righteousness and does unrighteous things, he will die in them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when a wicked man turns away from his wickedness and practices justice and righteousness, he will live through them.
speaker: Narrator

text: So, even though you say, “The Lord’s way is not fair,” I will judge each one of you according to his own ways, O house of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the twelfth year of our captivity, in the tenth month, on the fifth day of the month, a refugee from Jerusalem came to me and said, “The city has fallen.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the hand of the Lord had been upon me the evening before the survivor came, and the Lord had opened my mouth, so by the time the refugee came to me in the morning, my mouth was opened, and I was no longer unable to speak.
speaker: Narrator

text: The word of the Lord came to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Son of man, the inhabitants of these ruins in the land of Israel are saying, “Abraham was only one man, and he took possession of the land. We are many, and certainly the land has been given to us as a possession.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, say this to them. This is what the Lord God says. You eat meat with the blood still in it. You raise your eyes to your filthy idols. You shed blood, and still you think you will possess the land?
speaker: Narrator

text: You depend on your sword. You commit abominations. Each of you defiles his neighbor’s wife, and still you think you will possess the land?
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what you are to say to them. This is what the Lord God says. As I live, those who are in the ruins will fall by the sword, and I will give anyone in the open country to the wild animals to eat, and those in strongholds and caves will die by the plague.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will make the land a desolate wasteland. Its arrogant strength will cease, and the mountains of Israel will be so desolate that no one will travel through them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they will know that I am the Lord, when I make the land a desolate wasteland because of all the abominable things they have committed.
speaker: Narrator

text: What about you, son of man? Your countrymen, who are talking with each other about you beside the walls and in the doorways of the houses, say to one another, each one to a neighbor, “Come now and hear what the word is that is coming from the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They come to you as a group on behalf of the people, and they sit in front of you as if they were my people. They listen to your words but refuse to act on them, because they prefer to use their mouths for obscene talk, and their hearts pursue their wrongful gain.
speaker: Narrator

text: You see, to them you are like someone who sings erotic songs with a beautiful voice, who is an excellent musician. So they listen to your words, but they are not obeying them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when this comes—and come it will—they will know that a prophet has been among them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The word of the Lord came to me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Son of man, prophesy against the shepherds of Israel. Prophesy and say to those shepherds that this is what the Lord God says.
Woe to you, shepherds of Israel, who have been shepherding for themselves. Aren’t shepherds supposed to shepherd for the benefit of the sheep?
speaker: Narrator

text: You eat the fat. You wear the wool. You slaughter the fattened ones—but you do not shepherd the flock.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have not strengthened the weak. You have not healed the sick. You have not bound up the injured. You have not brought back the strays, and you have not searched for the lost. Instead you have abused them with force and with violence.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they scattered, because there was no shepherd, and they became food for all the wild animals. My sheep scattered and
speaker: Narrator

text: wandered all over the mountains and on every high hill. Over the face of the whole earth, my flock was scattered, with no one looking for them and no one searching for them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, shepherds, hear the word of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: As surely as I live, declares the Lord God, because my flock has become plunder, and because my flock has become food for all the wild animals, because they have no shepherd and my shepherds did not concern themselves about my flock, but the shepherds took care of themselves instead of taking care of my flock,
speaker: Narrator

text: therefore, you shepherds, hear the word of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Lord God says. I am against the shepherds. Watch! I will remove my flock from their hand. I will remove them from taking care of the sheep, and no longer will those shepherds take care of themselves. I will rescue my flock from their mouths, so that they will no longer be food for them.
speaker: Narrator

text: For this is what the Lord God says. Here I am. I myself will seek the welfare of my flock and carefully search for them.
speaker: Narrator

text: As a shepherd searches for his flock when his sheep that were with him have been scattered, so I will search for my flock and rescue them from all the places where they were scattered on a day of clouds and thick darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will bring them out from the peoples and gather them from the countries and bring them to their own soil. I will shepherd them on the mountains of Israel, in the valleys, and in all the settlements of the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will lead them into good pasture, and their grazing land will be on the high mountains of Israel. There they will lie down in good grazing land, and they will pasture on rich pasture on the mountains of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: I myself will shepherd my flock. I myself will let them lie down, declares the Lord God.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will seek the lost. I will bring back the strays. I will bind up the injured. I will strengthen the weak. I will destroy the fat and the strong, and I will shepherd them with justice.

text: What about you, my flock? This is what the Lord God says. I am going to judge between one sheep and another, between the rams and the male goats.

speaker: Narrator

text: Then my flock has to feed on what your feet have trampled and drink what your feet have muddied.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, this is what the Lord God says to them. I myself am going to judge between the fat sheep and the thin sheep.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because you have shoved them with your side and shoulder and butted all the weak ones with your horns, until you scattered them abroad,
speaker: Narrator

text: I will save my flock so that they will not become plunder anymore. In this way I will judge between one sheep and another.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I will raise up over them one shepherd, and he will tend them. My servant David will tend them, and he will be their shepherd.
speaker: Narrator

text: I, the Lord, will be their God, and my servant David will be the prince among them. I, the Lord, have spoken.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I will establish a covenant of peace with them, and I will rid the land of wild animals, so they may live securely in the wilderness and sleep in the forests.

text: I will make them and the area around my hill a blessing. I will send the rain showers down in their season. They will be showers of blessing.

text: The trees in the field will yield their fruit, and the earth will yield its produce. They will be secure on their own land and know that I am the Lord, when I break the bars of their yoke and rescue them from the hand of those who enslaved them.
speaker: Narrator

text: No more will they be plundered by the nations, nor will wild animals devour them. They will live in security, with no one to make them afraid.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will establish for them farmland famous for its crops, so that they will no longer be carried off by famine that is taking place in the land. They will no longer bear the scorn of the nations.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will know that I, the Lord their God, am with them, and that they, the house of Israel, are my people, declares the Lord God.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are my flock of sheep, the sheep of my pasture, and you are my people, and I am your God, declares the Lord God.
speaker: Narrator

text: The word of the Lord came to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Son of man, set your face against Mount Seir and prophesy against it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Say this to it.
This is what the Lord God says. I am against you, Mount Seir. I will stretch out my hand against you and make you a desolate wasteland.

text: I will make your cities ruins, and you will be desolate. Then you will know that I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because you cherished an ancient hatred and turned the Israelites over to the sword at the time of their disaster, at the time of their final punishment,
speaker: Narrator

text: therefore, as I live, declares the Lord God, I will subject you to bloodshed, and bloodshed will pursue you. Because you did not hate bloodshed, bloodshed will pursue you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will make Mount Seir a desolate wasteland and cut off from it all those who flee from it and want to return.

speaker: Narrator

text: I will make you desolate forever, and your cities will not be re-inhabited. Then you will know that I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because you said, “These two nations and these two lands will be mine, and we will possess them, even though the Lord was there,”
speaker: Narrator

speaker: Narrator

text: Then you will know that I, the Lord, have heard all the contemptuous statements that you uttered against the mountains of Israel: “They have been devastated and given to us for food.”
speaker: Narrator

text: With your mouth you made proud boasts against me and heaped up arrogant words against me. I have heard it myself.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Lord God says. While the whole world celebrates, I will make you a desolation.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because you celebrated when you took possession of the house of Israel because it was desolate, so will I deal with you. Mount Seir, you will be desolate, along with all of Edom. Then they will know that I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now you, son of man, prophesy to the mountains of Israel and say this.
Mountains of Israel, hear the word of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is what the Lord God says.
Because the enemy said about you, “Aha! At last! The ancient heights have become our possession,”
speaker: Narrator

text:
you are to prophesy and say, “This is what the Lord God says.”
Because they have devastated and crushed you from all sides, so that you would become the possession of the rest of the nations and a subject of people’s gossip and slander,
speaker: Narrator

text: therefore, you mountains of Israel, hear the word of the Lord God. This is what the Lord God says to the mountains, hills, valleys, ravines, desolate ruins, and abandoned cities, which have become a source of plunder and are subjected to ridicule by the rest of the nations all around.
speaker: Narrator

text: So, this is what the Lord God says. Without fail, in my fiery zeal I am speaking against the rest of the nations and against all of Edom, because they took my land as their own with whole-hearted glee and deep-seated contempt, and they occupied its pastureland.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, prophesy about the land of Israel and say to the mountains, hills, valleys, and ravines: This is what the Lord God says. In my zeal and wrath I am speaking because you have endured the taunts of the nations.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, this is what the Lord God says. I swear with an uplifted hand that the nations all around you will endure taunts against them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you, O mountains of Israel, will shoot forth your branches and bear your fruit for my people Israel, because they will soon come back.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yes, I am on your side. I will look on you with favor, and your land will be cultivated and planted.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will multiply people for you, for the whole house of Israel, all of it. The cities will be resettled and the ruins rebuilt.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will multiply both people and animals on you. They will multiply and be fruitful. I will resettle you as you were in earlier times and do more good for you than I did when you began. Then you will know that I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will cause people, my people Israel, to walk over you. They will take possession of you. You will become their inheritance, and never again will you deprive them of their children.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Lord God says. Because some people say to you, “You devour your people and keep on depriving your nations of their children,”
speaker: Narrator

text: therefore, you will no longer devour your people or deprive your nations of their children, declares the Lord God.
speaker: Narrator

text: No longer will I let you hear the taunts of the nations or endure the scorn of the peoples. Never again will you deprive your nations of their children, declares the Lord God.
speaker: Narrator

text: The word of the Lord came to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Son of man, when the house of Israel was living on their own soil, they defiled it by their conduct and by their actions. To me their conduct was as unclean as the blood of a woman’s period.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I poured out my wrath on them because of the blood they had poured on the ground and because of the filthy idols with which they had defiled it,
speaker: Narrator

text: and I scattered them among the nations so that they were dispersed among the countries. On the basis of their conduct and their actions I judged them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then when they came to the various nations, they profaned my holy name when people said about them, “These are the people of the Lord, but they had to leave his land.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So I was concerned about my holy name, which the house of Israel had profaned among the various nations to which they had come.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, say this to the house of Israel. This is what the Lord God says. I am about to act, O house of Israel, not for your sake, but for the sake of my holy name, which you have profaned among the nations to which you have gone.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will sanctify my great name, which has been profaned among the nations, which you profaned among them. Then the nations will know that I am the Lord, declares the Lord God, when I reveal myself as holy in front of their eyes through you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will take you from among the nations. I will gather you from all the lands, and I will bring you to your own soil.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will sprinkle purifying water on you, and you will be clean. I will cleanse you from all your impurity and from all your filthy idols.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I will give you a new heart and put a new spirit inside you. I will remove the heart of stone from your body and give you a heart of flesh.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will put my Spirit within you and will cause you to walk in my statutes, and you will carefully observe my ordinances.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you will live in the land I gave your fathers. You will be my people, and I will be your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will save you from all your impurity. I will summon the grain and make it plentiful. I will not bring famine upon you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will increase the fruit on the trees and the produce in the fields, so that you will never again suffer disgrace among the nations because of famine.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you will remember your evil ways and your deeds that were not good, and you will loathe yourselves on account of your guilty deeds and your abominations.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is not for your sake that I am about to act, declares the Lord God. Let this be known to you! Be ashamed and embarrassed because of your ways, O house of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Lord God says. On the day that I cleanse you from all your guilty deeds, I will resettle your cities, and the ruins will be rebuilt.
speaker: Narrator

text: The desolate land will be cultivated instead of remaining desolate in the sight of every passerby.
speaker: Narrator

text: People will say, “This land that was devastated has become like the Garden of Eden, and the cities that were ruined, desolate, and destroyed are now fortified and inhabited.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the nations that remain around you will know that I, the Lord, have rebuilt the places that were destroyed and have replanted what was desolate. I, the Lord, have spoken, and I will do it.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Lord God says. I will also allow the house of Israel to ask me to do this for them. I will multiply them so their people are like flocks.
speaker: Narrator

text: Like flocks consecrated for sacrifice, like the flocks of Jerusalem on its festival days, so the ruined cities will be filled with flocks of people. Then they will know that I am the Lord.

text: The hand of the Lord was upon me. He brought me out by the Spirit of the Lord and set me down in the middle of a valley, which was full of bones.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had me pass through them and go all over among them. There were very many on the valley floor, and they were very dry.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to me, “Son of man, can these dry bones live?” I answered, “Lord God, you know.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said to me, “Prophesy to these bones and say to them, ‘Dry bones, hear the word of the Lord.’”
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is what the Lord God says to these bones.
I am about to make breath enter you so that you will live.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will attach tendons to you. I will put flesh back on you. I will cover you with skin and put breath in you, and you will live. Then you will know that I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I prophesied as I had been commanded, and as I was prophesying there was a noise, a rattling, as the bones came together, one bone connecting to another.
speaker: Narrator

text: As I watched, tendons were attached to them, then flesh grew over them, and skin covered them. But there was no breath in them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said to me, “Prophesy to the wind. Prophesy, son of man, and say to the wind that this is what the Lord God says. From the four winds, come, O wind, and breathe into these slain so that they may live.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So I prophesied as he commanded me. Breath entered them, and they came back to life. They stood on their feet, a very, very large army.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said to me, “Son of man, these bones are the whole house of Israel. They are saying, ‘Our bones are dried up. Our hope is lost. We have been completely cut off.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, prophesy and say to them that this is what the Lord God says. My people, I am going to open your graves and raise you up from your graves and bring you back to the soil of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you will know that I am the Lord, when I open your graves and raise you up from your graves, O my people.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will put my Spirit in you, and you will live. I will settle you on your own land, and you will know that I, the Lord, have spoken, and I have done it, declares the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The word of the Lord came to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now you, son of man, take one piece of wood and write on it: “Belonging to Judah and belonging to the people of Israel associated with him.” Then take another piece of wood and write on it: “Belonging to Joseph, Ephraim’s piece of wood, and the whole house of Israel associated with him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then hold one piece of wood close to the other to make a single board for yourself, so that they are one in your hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: When your countrymen say to you, “Won’t you tell us what you mean by these things?”
speaker: Narrator

text: you tell them, “This is what the Lord God says. I am going to take the piece of wood which is in the hand of Ephraim, which is for Joseph and for the tribes of Israel associated with him, and I will attach it to the piece of wood for Judah. In this way I will make them one board, so that they will be one in my hand.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The boards on which you will write should be in your hand in front of their eyes.

text: Then say this to them. This is what the Lord God says. I am going to take the people of Israel from among the nations where they have gone, and I will gather them from all around, and I will bring them to their own land.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will make them one nation in the land, on the mountains of Israel, and one king will be king for all of them. Never again will they be two nations, and never again will they be divided into two kingdoms.
speaker: Narrator

text: Never again will they defile themselves with their filthy idols, with their disgusting practices, and with all their rebellious actions. I will save them from all their backsliding by which they have sinned, and I will cleanse them. They will be my people, and I will be their God.
speaker: Narrator

text: My servant David will be King over them, and they will all have one Shepherd. They will follow my ordinances and be conscientious about keeping my statutes.

text: They will live on the land I gave my servant Jacob, where your fathers lived. They will live there permanently—they, their children, and their grandchildren—and my servant David will be their prince forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will make a covenant of peace with them. It will be an everlasting covenant with them. I will establish them, and I will multiply them and set my sanctuary in their midst forever.

text: Then the nations will know that I, the Lord, make Israel holy when my holy place is in their midst forever.

text: The word of the Lord came to me.

and say this.

Its population had been brought out from among the peoples, and all of them were now living securely.

text: This is what the Lord God says. Are you the one I spoke about in earlier days through my servants, the prophets of Israel? In those days didn’t they prophesy for many years that I would bring you against Israel?
